SUSIE GHARIB, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Good evening everyone. I'm Susie Gharib. Home prices head higher, as the housing recovery digs in.

TOM HUDSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: I'm Tom Hudson. McDonald's (NYSE:MCD) shares tumble though. The fast food giant posts its first monthly sales drop in nearly a decade.

GHARIB: And the U.S. futures market, it's been hit by scandal, but investors are still buying in. We continue our look at confidence and the markets.

HUDSON: That and more tonight here on NBR.

There's more evidence tonight the housing market is recovering. Two reports today show home prices jumped significantly in the second quarter. And it's a classic story of supply and demand. Fewer homes for sale has helped push up prices for those looking for buyers. Here's the data. Real estate data firm CoreLogic (NYSE:CLGX) finds home prices up 6 percent. Freddie Mac's survey has prices up 4.8 percent. This are the largest quarter over quarter price hikes in at least seven years. Housing had been a drag on the economy, but fewer homes for sale and record low mortgage rates have really continued to repair the sector even though consumers remain cautious.

And we saw the latest data that (INAUDIBLE) that caution from McDonald's (NYSE:MCD) today. July sales at the fast food restaurant fell flat, surprising investors and sending its stock lower. Sales at U.S. stores open for more than a year fell slightly last month, down 0.1 of one percent. That marks the first time in almost a decade monthly sales didn't rise. Like other analysts, Morningstar's RJ Hottovy expects sales to slow, but thought they'd still be positive.

RJ HOTTOVY, SR. RETAIL ANALYST, MORNINGSTAR: Whether it be sluggish wage growth and an uneven housing recovery and just a lot of headlines about a worsening global macroeconomic picture, I think a combination of those have definitely put consumers in a more value oriented mindset and that's something that will probably continue in the months to come. This may not be the last month that McDonalds puts up a slightly negative same store sales results for the U.S.

GHARIB: McDonalds was one of the big losers here on the big board today and that pressured stocks. But the Dow still eked out a fourth day of gains. Here are the numbers. The blue chips rose seven points, the NASDAQ slipped four and a half and the S&P added nearly a point.

So get ready for a pull back in stocks. That's what our market guest is telling his clients. He's Scott Wren, senior equity strategist at Wells Fargo (NYSE:WFC) Advisors. So Scott, let's talk about that pull back. When, how big and why are you thinking that?

SCOTT WREN, SR. EQUITY STRATEGIST, WELLS FARGO ADVISORS: Well, Susie, I think probably over the next couple of months, we are very susceptible to headlines out of Europe. I think that the ECB will certainly be in at some point buying Spanish and Italian debt. But I don't think it's going to be as soon as the market wants. Much of this rally was based on what the Fed might do, also what the ECB might do. So I think it's very possible the Fed does do some easing. I think it's very possible and very likely the ECB does go in and buy some bonds. I just don't think it's going to be as soon. I think the market's a little bit ahead of itself. I think probably you could see certainly a 5 percent pullback and possibly upwards of a 10 percent pullback, but really on a pullback like that, we're looking at that as an opportunity. We want our clients in there taking advantage of a pullback like that and adding to positions.

GHARIB: Let me pick up on some of the points that you made there, first of all, about policy action. Investors do seem to be banking on the Federal Reserve and the European central bank doing something. Let's say they do. Is that a long term or just a temporary boost to the market?

WREN: I think that -- let's look at the Federal Reserve. If they do a QE3, in my opinion I would have to doubt the effectiveness as that. I almost feel there's kind of pushing on a string. I think there's a lot of liquidity in the system. It's just that there's no velocity of money. Confidence is down and people don't want to really borrow and spend. The ECB is in a much more dire situation. Spain and Italy both have a lot of debt this year that they need to roll over and there's just not very many investors stepping up to buy that. So I think the ECB is in a very dire situation. They are likely to act sooner. But let's be certain. If we have sub-two percent GDP growth and 8 percent plus unemployment, the Federal Reserve is not going to sit on its hands and do nothing.

GHARIB: You just tell people (ph) fundamentals there. But let me ask you, let me make the positive case and there are a lot of market guests who come on our program. They point to those housing numbers, for example. Housing is making a recovery. We just talked about that at the top of the show, also corporate profits coming in better than expected. They always talk about some kind of Fed action. But none of that resonates with you. You're still (INAUDIBLE) on a pullback.

WREN: Well I think and let me say this -- our year end target on the S&P 500 is 1400 to 1450, so we're inside at the bottom range of that target. And I'm very confident in that year end target. I just think that we came to this level a little bit too fast. I think we came to this level because of anticipated action by central banks. That's probably a little further out than what the market thinks.

GHARIB: We have about 20 seconds left. Talk to us about investor confidence. We're running a whole series this week about this subject. What are your clients telling you about their confidence level?

WREN: Retail investor confidence level is low. They're fearful. They're afraid to get back into the market no matter what the valuations are. So our clients have a lot of cash on the sidelines, and one of my main jobs is to point out to people that you're going to be living longer. You're going to need to grow your money. You're going to need to participate in the global and U.S. growth and one of the best ways to do that is going to continue to be stocks. You need to be invested in the stock market.

GHARIB: Lots of good information. Scott, thanks a lot, Scott Wren at Wells Fargo (NYSE:WFC) Advisors.

WREN: Thanks, Susie.

DIANE EASTABROOK, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: I'm Diane Eastabrook. Still ahead, I'll tell you why the futures market isn't what it used to be.

HUDSON: Fine coffee (ph) at some Starbucks (NASDAQ:SBUX) in the future, may only take your name. The catch is you'll have to have a special pay with Square ap on your smart phone that announces your arrival at the cash register. It's part of a new partnership announced today between Starbucks (NASDAQ:SBUX) and Square. That's the mobile payments start-up run by one of the co-founders of Twitter. The deal calls for Starbucks (NASDAQ:SBUX) to invest $25 million in Square. Square will also process all of Starbucks' credit card payments, at significant savings. Earlier today, NBR's Erika Miller spoke with Starbucks (NASDAQ:SBUX) CEO Howard Schultz and Square CEO Jack Dorsey.

ERIKA MILLER, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: I would imagine that every big tech company has been beating at your door begging for a mobile payment deal. What do you think that Jack and Square is the right partnership for Starbucks (NASDAQ:SBUX)?

HOWARD SCHULTZ, CEO, STARBUCKS: It's true that we have spoken to most of the high profile blue chip tech companies, all of whom are trying to crack the code on how to monetize mobile payments. I think when we met Square and then Jack, there were a few things that really stuck one. One was like minded values of both companies and I think Square's singular focus on payments and their level of innovation and entrepreneurialship (sic) and understanding of the Starbucks (NASDAQ:SBUX) experience quickly separated them from the pack and it was a very easy choice for us.

MILLER: And Jack, talk about what this deal means for Square. Is it more than just a positive development? Is this a game changer for your company?

JACK DORSEY, CEO, SQUARE: Absolutely. It really proves out that the technology we built scales from the individual and the small business all the way up to the very largest organizations in the world.

MILLER: Until this point, Square has been focused on small, even micro businesses. Does this partnership signal a new focus towards big global companies?

DORSEY: It's really around that scale. We're building a technology that should be treated as a utility, that an individual can come to or a very large organization can come to it and use it in very similar ways.

MILLER: Howard, it's one thing to encourage local payments in Starbucks (NASDAQ:SBUX). It's another thing to make a $25 million investment in a company that's not yet profitable. Why did you go that route?

SCHULTZ: I think we've all seen as consumers that the smart phone has really become the primary device in our life. The investment we're making of $i25 million is a significant vote of confidence to Square and Jack. We think that is going to create shareholder value for our shareholders.

MILLER: Jack, this partnership comes at a time when you're facing stiff competition from the likes of eBay (NASDAQ:EBAY), from the likes of Intuit (NASDAQ:INTU), Google (NASDAQ:GOOG), big competitors. Is it game on now? Are there going to be a rush to sign up big corporate partners?

DORSEY: We do something very specific which is not just focus on the mechanics of payments, but actually the experience around it. Everything from the point of sale all the way to what's in the consumers' pocket. And that bridge between the two is what is powerful and what is meaningful.

MILLER: Howard, I'd like to get your assessment of the global economy. Obviously you're a big global corporation. What do you see in terms of trends? Are consumers becoming more willing to spend? Is your ticket price going up? What can you tell me about Europe?

SCHULTZ: I think with 18,000 stores in 60 countries, every single day we have a window into consumer confidence and consumer behavior. It's no surprise that over the last few months there's been a significant level of pressure on consumer behavior and consumer spending in Europe. I don't think any of us see that changing any time soon.

GHARIB: This deal is obviously a big vote of confidence for mobile payments. Do you think (INAUDIBLE).

DORSEY: It is definitely disappearing. I can't imagine my grandmother leaving it at home. But I think what's always been true about payments is that the merchant always needs to accept whatever comes over the counter. They always want to make the sale. So it's important (INAUDIBLE)to that, but at the same time recognize the technologies that are coming to make it easier, to make it faster and improve the experience.

MILLER: hank you both very much for joining us.

SCHULTZ: Thank you.

DORSEY: Thank you. Thank you very much.

GHARIB: If you live in a political swing state, chances are you've seen a political ad, or two or 20 in the past few months. This year's presidential campaign season already is on pace to be the most expensive on record. And with the so-called super pacs able to raise unlimited amounts of money for political advertisements, the spending is expected to rise. Sylvia Hall reports.

SYLVIA HALL, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Summer may be ending, but the fight for the presidency is heating up. You just need a remote control to see it play out.

DARRELL WEST, VP & DIR., GOV. STUDIES, BROOKINGS: The tide does not rise evenly. Some battleground states tend to get all the money and last time around, the top 11 states got 90 percent of the spending.

HALL: Television campaign spending is on pace to break records. And this year, super pacs are set to spend huge sums of money on advertising, for or against the candidates.

JACK POOR, VP, TELEVISION BUREAU OF ADVERTISING: Romney and his collaborators will probably spend a billion. Obama will be less than that, maybe $800 million.

HALL: But most of the country won't see the ads that spring from all that cash. So far this year, spending is concentrated in nine swing states. By law, campaigns pay fairly low rates for television ad space. But for super pacs, it's a different game. Some super pacs pay as much as twice what a campaign pays for airtime.

POOR: The irony is there are a very few number of undecided voters this year, so we're going to spend $3 billion essentially trying to persuade 5 to 10 percent of the electorate in nine states.

HALL: If you're in one of those states, you'll have a front row seat for a presidential campaign that's shaping up to be one of the most intense and negative on record. Just listen to some of the most recent attack ads to hit the airwaves.

CAMPAIGN AD: Under Obama's plan, you wouldn't have to work, you wouldn't have to train for a job. They just send you your welfare check.

CAMPAIGN AD: I do not think Mitt Romney realizes what he's done to anyone. And furthermore I do not think Mitt Romney is concerned.

WEST: It's way, way negative, somewhere north of 70 percent negative to 30 percent positive. We think that's going to continue and perhaps get worse. And one of the big reasons is the pacs, the super pacs. They're providing the bulk of the Republican spending right now and a significant portion of the Democratic as well.

HALL: Nobody knows yet how all this political spending could affect the businesses who usually advertise on television year round. The super pac money could raise ad rates for everyone. Sylvia Hall, NBR, Washington.

HUDSON: Toyota (NYSE:TM) says it's only a matter of time before it starts building more cars in North America and you can thank its native currency. A strong Japanese yen is clobbering the country's bottom line or rather the company's bottom line on U.S. exports. Toyota's U.S. sales chief Jim Lentz today said the auto maker's looking at moving production of Lexus ES sedans from Japan to the U.S. But he says before making such a costly move, the company will keep monitoring the yen. Lentz also re- affirmed Toyota's U.S. sales forecast at 14.3 million vehicles this year, predicting a pick up in sales after the presidential election.

GHARIB: Those rising home prices we told you about a little earlier in the program are also helping Fannie Mae. It reported today a solid second quarter profit just a day after Freddie Mac did the same. The government controlled mortgage giant earned $5 billion. That works out to $0.37 a share. The gains mark Fannie Mae's best quarter in a decade. So as a result, the company didn't need to ask for more taxpayer help and Tom, that's kind of significant because since the financial crisis, Fannie Mae has relied on loans from American taxpayers something along the lines of $116 billion.

HUDSON: A good development there, positive news in housing here tonight. And that's got a little bit of the market going here today Susie. In our "Market Focus" the major stock indices really kind of meandered around for most of the day before closing essentially flat. The S&P 500 did have a choppy session, trading in a very narrow range. The index saw its worst and best levels of the day this morning, creating only an eight point trading range, very narrow. It ended higher by a fraction, still enough though for yes a new three-month high tonight. Trading volume moderate, 636 million shares on the big board, just under 1.9 billion moving on the NASDAQ. Then the consumer was in focus for the markets. The consumer staples sector had the best gains, up 0.6 of a percent, while the consumer discretionary sector was the biggest drag, down 0.4 of one percent.

Now consumer staples are those things we tend to buy because we need them. And Dean Foods (NYSE:DF) stock saw a big pop as the company plans to spin off its Horizon organic and Silk soy milk business. Lots of folks wanting Dean Foods (NYSE:DF) stock today, shooting up 40.6 percent. Volume more than -- jumped seven fold with the stock up to its highest price in two and a half years tonight. The firm has hinted for some time about a possible spin-off, wanting to separate its faster growing business from its traditional dairy operations. That news came after the company reported a stronger than expected second quarter helped out by lower costs. Earnings at Dean Foods (NYSE:DF) a nickel better than estimates. The company also raised its guidance for the year. And despite the U.S. drought's impact on grain prices for dairy producers, Dean Foods (NYSE:DF) does not think the impact on dairy prices will be as bad as some predict.

Meantime, consumer discretionary companies, firms selling things we want but may not need, were under some pressure thanks to travel websites. Priceline.com topped the losers in this area, down 17.3 percent. Among S&P 500 traded stocks, the lowest price since February after the company's financial forecast came in short of expectations. Fellow online travel site Orbitz Worldwide (NYSE:OWW) saw even bigger loss, losing more than a quarter of its value. Its outlook is below expectations as well. Tripadvisor lost 4.9 percent as the sector moved lower.

Meantime, homebuilding stocks - here we go -- higher prices thanks to the two reports we mentioned at the beginning of the program tonight showing that home prices were climbing. This exchange-traded fund in made up for homebuilding stocks. With today's 0.8 of a percent gain, it's at its highest price since May and less than $0.50 away from a four-year high.

On HP, Hewlett-Packard (NYSE:HPQ), ticker HPQ, been struggling for a couple of years, hit by CEO turnover and its traditional computer business really under pressure by tablets and smart phones. The company warned it will take an $8 billion write down due to a drop in its stock and business in its services unit. But excluding that massive charge, it raised its adjusted earnings forecast for the third quarter. That positive news in shares certainly responded positively, rising 2.4 percent, heavy traded HPQ today. Shares coming off an eight-year low earlier hit this month.

After closing just below a five-year high, media giant News Corp (NASDAQ:NWS) may be one to watch tomorrow. After the closing bell, shares sank rather 2.5 percent from this closing price. The company reported disappointing revenues. The company is preparing to spin off its newspaper publishing business from its television and film operations.

It was a mixed day for the five most actively traded ETFs. Only the S&P 500 and emerging markets exchange-traded funds eked out some very small gains. And that is tonight's "Market Focus."

All this week on NBR, we're talking about investor confidence in the markets. In the futures market, that confidence has been hit by the bankruptcy of MF Global and the admitted fraud at PFG Best. Farmers started trading futures in Chicago in the middle of the 19th century. Today, pension funds, hedge funds, individual investors have millions of dollars s on the line in corn, soybeans and other products. As Diane Eastabrook reports, some old-style market participants say these newer players are making it tougher for them to trade.

EASTABROOK: For 164 years farmers, grain elevators and food companies have used futures contracts traded in Chicago's commodity pits to hedge risk. Alpha Baking Company uses them to lock in prices for the wheat and natural gas used to make its breads and rolls. President Larry Marcucci's been trading futures for 30 years. About eight years ago he noticed it changed.

LARRY MARCUCCI, PRESIDENT, ALPHA BAKING: It used to be if the market went up a couple of cents or down a couple of cents a day that was a big deal. Then it started bouncing around double digits, $0.10, $0.20 a day.

EASTABROOK: Marcucci thinks so called financial participants are the reason. They include pension funds, commodity pool advisors and swap dealers who are trading futures as a way to make money. Together they can comprise anywhere from a quarter to nearly half of the market.

MARCUCCI: They add liquidity, but they can drive the market up and they can certainty drive the market down.

EASTABROOK: Speculators have always been crucial to the futures market, buying a grain contract a hedger is trying to sell. David Lehman is the managing director of commodity research and development at the CME Group (NASDAQ:CME). He says these new financial participants are improving the market for hedgers like Marcucci.

DAVID LEHMAN, MANAGING DIR., CME GROUP: Bringing a much broader array of participants into the market globally, as well as bringing more liquidity into the markets from investors has actually dampened volatility as you look at it statistically.

EASTABROOK: Lehman says what makes markets volatile is uncertainty. The current drought is a good example. And today hedgers and speculators have instant access to information and can trade electronically 24-7. University of Illinois agriculture economist Scott Irwin says that can make for faster moving markets.

SCOTT IRWIN, AGRICULTURE ECONOMIST, UNIV. OF ILLINOIS: But overall you'd have to say on net it likely means just simply, more efficient, quicker reacting markets to even more relevant information.

EASTABROOK: For Marcucci it now means spending a little less time on the plant floor and a bit more time monitoring commodity prices.

MARCUCCI: I've gone from maybe watching it maybe monthly, to weekly, to daily, to hourly.

EASTABROOK: Marcucci is still hedging. He says he thinks that future provide great assurance for his company. He's just being a little bit more cautious about how he uses them in the future. Tom?

HUDSON: Diane a lot of folks may be looking at the futures industry a little bit more cautiously now because of the bankruptcy of MF Global that we mentioned last fall and of course the fraud this summertime of PFG Best. How has that impacted the trusts of the futures industry?

EASTABROOK: Well, I think from a customer standpoint, where people like Marcucci, he trusts the markets. He thinks the markets are functioning as they should be. But I think there is some concern that there needs to be a bit more oversight, particularly of these futures commission merchants or FCMs like Peregrine and MF Global and regulators are doing more to look into those companies. They're doing more electronic audits and are also making extra sure that these companies are not co- mingling their money with customer money.

HUDSON: That's a key point and of course the MF Global collapse was just a trade that went wrong of course. With PFG, you've got admitted fraud. In fact after the MF Global failure, you sat in the same room with Russell Wasendorf, Sr. (ph) (INAUDIBLE) who is now at the center of the alleged fraud and he said that it was sacrosanct to keep separate customer money -- not to co-mingle it. But allegedly now we've learned he was ripping off customers.

EASTABROOK: Yeah. That's what took a lot of people -- it really stunned a lot of people, particularly me. I had interviewed him many times in the past. He was a very trusted member of the futures industry. And I think it goes back to what we were talking about earlier. There just needs to be more oversight and hopefully that's what we'll be seeing.

HUDSON: Looking at investor trust in the futures market here tonight. It's our Midwest bureau chief, Diane Eastabrook reporting for the CME Group (NASDAQ:CME) in Chicago. Thanks, Diane.

GHARIB: When it comes to confidence in the markets, tonight's commentator says market makers like Knight Capital have a great responsibility. Here's Joseph Cotterill, editor at the "Financial Times."

JOSEPH COTTERILL, EDITOR, FINANCIAL TIMES: Is it so terrifying that you should gut your 401(k) of stocks? You could say that the market itself absorbed Knight's problem trades pretty well last week. Those weird prices died down after that wild half hour. Even if you trade stocks day to day, that seems like better resilience than the big flash crash of two years ago. If you hold stocks for months or years, you could be feeling pretty insulated. Instead, the only downer on your confidence would be the merely atrocious economy.

But that can't be the whole story. Investors (INAUDIBLE) would be justified to have second thoughts over the bewildering pace of change in technology. These algorithms aren't space invaders or black swans. They're put in place by market makers locked in an arms race to be the fastest. They go fast to get you a tight stock quote. But weigh that against the unease when it goes wrong, or, as with Knight, there is no kill switch. It needs to be stoppable before it goes live. Otherwise, it's a dead market. I'm Joseph Cotterill.

HUDSON: Tomorrow on NBR, we're going to have some more details about the appetites of consumers, from the every day shopper to the higher end, more big retailers report results and outlooks. Second quarter earnings due in tomorrow from Kohl's (NYSE:KSS) and Nordstrom (NYSE:JWN).

GHARIB: And finally, Bond, James Bond has always been a box office hit and now British pay TV service BSkyB is banking on it. It announced the launch of a new 24 hour channel dedicated solely to what else, films featuring the one and only James Bond. The new channel will launch in October to mark the 50th anniversary of the franchise and will put the 007 films on (INAUDIBLE) Tom, these guys, they recently bought the rights to the Britain film franchise from MGM Studios.

HUDSON: I'll see if I can get that channel in the office. I'm a sucker any time those films are on.

GHARIB: I love them. But (INAUDIBLE) watch them in the middle of the report, of the movie. Anyway, that's NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for us for Wednesday this August 8. Have a great evening everyone and you too Tom. Take in a movie, a Bond movie.

HUDSON: Report, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, ergo (ph) online, nbr.com, back here tomorrow.

END

TOM HUDSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: As the nation's economic recovery slogs along, Wall Street puts the wraps on another rocky year.

MIKE RYAN, CHIEF INVEST. STRATEGIST, UBS WEALTH MANAGEMENT: I think we're going to get more of the same. We're going to get a lot of volatile markets and I think we're going to continue to trade off headlines.

HUDSON: 2011 ends with the major stock averages pretty much where they were one year ago. From oil to IPOs, what to expect from the year ahead. It's NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Friday, December 30th.

Good evening and thanks for joining us. Susie is off tonight. Investors say good bye to a year of wild market swings and lots of economic worries but also a year that ends very close to where it began for the major stock averages. With today's fractional losses for those averages, the broad market ended the year virtually unchanged. The blue chip Dow Jones Industrial Average managed to end the year on the upside rising 5.5 percent. The NASDAQ closed down this year almost 2 percent. How about the S&P 500, finishing with a loss of 4/100 of a percent, essentially in the same place it was at the end of last year. But for the 11th straight year, gold prices rallied, closing at $1,566 an ounce. That marks a 10 percent gain this year. After this roller coaster ride for investors, 2012 is set to begin with many of the same concerns and uncertainties. Suzanne Pratt reports from New York.

SUZANNE PRATT, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Tomorrow evening New York's famed Times Square will be filled with thousands of people celebrating the New Year. On Wall Street, however there will be far less partying as stock investors say good riddance to a tough year. 2011 has been volatile due to Europe's debt crisis, slow economic growth here at home and political uncertainty around the globe. And there's little unanimity among financial pros as to whether 2012 will be an up or down year for the major averages. Still most do agree trading will be sloppy and choppy.

MIKE RYAN, CHIEF INVEST. STRATEGIST, UBS WEALTH MANAGEMENT: I think we're going to get more of the same. We're going get a lot of volatile markets and I think we're going to continue to trade off headlines.

PRATT: And those headlines are likely to come out of Europe, at least in the first half of the year.

VADIM ZLOTINIKOV, CHIEF MARKET STRATEGIST, ALLIANCEBERNSTEIN: You have uncertainty as to what is the path that Europe is going to choose. If it is a path of extreme austerity, you could actually depress the U.S. companies earnings and the U.S. economic growth. If on the other hand it's some combination of monetary easing in a framework for reducing the deficit, that would be viewed by the market as more popular.

PRATT: No matter what happens in the Eurozone, U.S. economic growth is likely to be muted next year. Yes, there are signs the recovery is gaining momentum. But headwinds are still plentiful. Not only are job prospects for millions of Americans bleak, but the housing market remains in the cellar and there is one more factor likely to create uncertainty for investors in 2012, call it a global changing of the guard.

RYAN: Think about the countries that potentially face a change in leadership. The United States, China, France, India, Iran, Korea, you know, this is, these are countries that represent about half the world's GDP. So those leadership changes can also be add to the volatility of the markets.

PRATT: Before you head for the exits permanently, there are at least a few reasons to be positive about stocks in 2012. Corporate profits are expected to remain decent. Companies can still borrow at very low rates and don't forget the oodles of money in corporate coffers.

ZLOTINIKOV: Companies that are generating a lot of cash and are likely to increase the payout, likely to increase dividends, I want to be clear. This is not a new theme. It is actually an extremely crowded theme. It has been recommended by every single person in the world, doesn't make it wrong.

PRATT: Investor sentiment is still a big wild card for next year. Trading volume in the last few months has been very low, suggesting a serious lack of conviction. And that is unlikely to change until there's better clarity on Europe. Suzanne Pratt, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York.

HUDSON: All that uncertainty has lead for one of the best place for investors this year, it's the bond market. Most bond mutual funds did better than stock mutual fund funds in 2011. Mutual funds focused on U.S. government bonds gained 9 percent on the year while the average large-cap core stock fund lost 0.3 of 1 percent. What to do after those gains? Well, bond expert Larry Swedroe of Buckingham Asset Management shares a portfolio suggestion for the New Year.

LARRY SWEDROE, RESEARCH DIR., BUCKINGHAM ASSET MANAGEMENT: I think you should have a well thought out plan, an asset allocation, maybe 60 percent stock, 40 percent bonds or if you are older maybe it is 40 percent bonds and 60 percent stocks. And then you want to have the discipline to stay the course. And that means after a bond run, you are going to be selling bonds at high prices, meaning you are going to have a nice profit, you get to sell high. And you should be buying stocks at low prices when expected returns are high.

HUDSON: You can hear more of what Larry says about investing in 2012. The full interview is on our web site, just go to nbr.com.

On the eve of the New Year and new tension between the west and Iran. The country has threatened to close the Strait of Hormuz, the narrow waterway linking the Persian Gulf to the Arabian Sea. Seventeen million barrels of oil move through the strait every day. And it's about 20 percent of all oil traded worldwide. Iran has threatened to close the strait if it faces new sanctions over its nuclear program. John Kilduff is with us, founding partner at Again Capital with us at the NASDAQ. John, you've been following the oil market for years. How serious is the oil market taking this new threat?

JOHN KILDUFF, FOUNDING PARTNER, AGAIN CAPITAL: It's taking it relatively seriously. And it's certainly ratcheted up here over the past several weeks. To the western countries' credit, for once, the sanctions are biting in Iran. And that's why you are seeing a reaction by the Iranians to them. And while though I think that they are certainly capable of causing trouble in the strait, we're not there yet in terms of being on the precipice. There's a lot of diplomatic dancing work to go on before that occurs.

HUDSON: It hasn't impacted global supply yet. Most of that oil that runs through the Strait of Hormuz heads to Asia. We know that China has slowed down a little bit. But does this threaten the Asian economies?

KILDUFF: Well, it will. It will threaten all our economies if it were to get blocked, even momentarily, even if it is just a single barge let's say in the one of the two shipping lanes. The headline is going to hit the tape. We're all going to buy it and not sort out the details until much later. Because look, it's most of the Saudi oil. It's Iraq's southern production which is half of that country's output that goes through that narrow strait, UAE and Iranian oil for that matter. So it will be a shortage of oil that can't be made up by anyone so that is why the stakes are so high.

HUDSON: John, what about the ability to reroute some of that Persian Gulf oil to pipelines and take it up to the north?

KILDUFF: It really is not an option. It's not going to be a sufficient ability. Like I said, the (INAUDIBLE) oil facility off Saudi Arabia's coast which I like to call the world's oil aorta really is irreplaceable, just too much of a volume of oil to displace in any fashion.

HUDSON: John, we know it is a global market for crude. U.S. crude, domestic oil, meantime, just shy of $100 a barrel as we wind up this year. How about the impact if this threat continues to raise tensions with the Mideast?

KILDUFF: Yeah, like you said, it is a global market. And the price reverberates around the world no matter where the shortage is. We saw what the Libyan outage did to the Brent crude oil prices and what it did to the west Texas prices as well. It kept it sustained at levels much higher than we otherwise would have been. And even this Iranian situation has probably added a good $15 to $20 a barrel in geo-political premium right now.

HUDSON: And finally what about the demand picture in the first quarter with Europe still in question?

KILDUFF: It's going to be very much in doubt. Not only here we're seeing gasoline demand consistently down about 5 percent week in and week out and the Chinese economy is a big question mark. The data we're getting from there is pointing to a slowdown. And whether or not it's going to be significant or not, what remains to be seen. But they are the swing demand center. So the way we talk about Saudi Arabia's oil being so precious to supply, China's demand is equally as precious on the demand side of the equation.

HUDSON: That's the outlook as we move into the New Year for oil. John, happy New Year to you.

KILDUFF: Happy New Year to you.

HUDSON: John Kilduff with us tonight from Again Capital.

From oil to IPOs this year saw the return of the Internet initial public offering and lots of hype surrounding the trading debuts of stocks like Linkedin and Zynga (NASDAQ:ZNGA). But investors did not always buy into the hype. Joya Dass tonight looks back at the year's newest stocks and the IPO everybody is waiting for next year.

JOYA DASS, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: While the markets renewed their appetite for companies going public in 2011, it wasn't the blockbuster year as some had hoped.

JAMES KRAPFEL, IPO STRATEGIST, MORNINGSTAR: The companies that went public in 2011, on average under performed the S&P 500 by 12 percentage points.

DASS: Big tech IPOs Linkedin, Groupon and game maker Zynga (NASDAQ:ZNGA) started off with a bang, but finished the year in some cases with a dull thud.

KRAPFEL: Groupon was the second one. They were up about 25, 30 percent on the first day, immediately in the first couple of weeks fell about 40 percent. But it has shot back up above its IPO price, which is why, we along with others are very skeptical of that company and their business model.

DASS: This year's top IPO performers included Imperva, a leader in data security. GNC Holdings, a mall favorite featuring nutrition bars. Tangoe, a telecom group and Tesoro Logistics, a refiner and marketer of petroleum-based products. This year's worst IPO performers included China Century Dragon Media, a Chinese television media buyer. Friendfinder Networks, a dating web site, Imperial Holdings, a specialty finance company and finally Kips Bay Medical, which develops products such as mesh stents for use in bypass surgery. And that brings us to the IPO market for 2012.

DAVID MENLOW, PRESIDENT,IPOFINANCIAL.COM (BY TELEPHONE): The balance sheets of the companies coming public, the deleveraged aspects of those companies that are coming public, all point to a very strong cycle for the IPO market. And one that is going to put the individual investor or the institutional investor in a very advantaged position because valuation models are at historic lows.

DASS: Companies David is watching out for include Gogo, the company that provides Internet access aboard planes. Software company with a focus on the TV industry NDS Group Holdings and marketing company Exact Target (NYSE:TGT). And then there is the 800 pound gorilla in the IPO market for 2012 better known as Facebook.

KRAPFEL: They have a prospectus ready to go, could file for the first time in January and looks like they're targeting a second quarter 2012 filing. They're targeting a $100 billion valuation and look to raise $10 billion.

DASS: With Facebook revenues expected to top $4 billion for 2011, investors might just like this IPO. Joya Dass for NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York.

HUDSON: Still ahead from us tonight, pain from paying into college to paying it off. It was one of the big issues for the "Occupy Wall Street" movement. We'll take a look at the state of student loans.

A quiet ending today through the year with the major averages sinking just a bit, capping really a volatile year for investors. Let's go ahead and take a look at tonight's "Market Focus." Before we take a look back at the year that was, we will look at today's trading activity with stocks sliding in to the New Year's holiday and the long holiday weekend. The Dow Industrials Average spent almost the entire session in the red. The index continued dropping into the closing bell, ending the session down a little more than one half of 1 percent.

But as we reported at the beginning of the program, blue chips were the stocks of interest for investors. The Dow gained 5.5 percent this year, outpacing the other major stock averages. And leading the area for the Dow, McDonald's, MCD, shares shooting up more than 30 percent this year as its North American business continued to strengthen even as the company raised some menu prices making up for higher commodity prices.

On the bottom meantime, the worst Dow stock, Bank of America (NYSE:BAC) losing more than half its value as B of A continues battling the weak housing market -- worries about its financial stability and questions about its corporate leadership. Earlier this month, Bank of America (NYSE:BAC) shares dipped below $5 per share. Tonight they are just above $5.50 per share.

The stocks had plenty of ups and downs clearly this year, but it was not as volatile as some recent years. Thirty eight percent of trading sessions this year had swings of at least 1 percent for the S&P 500. While that is more than last year, it's actually less volatile than what we saw in 2009.

The year end numbers for the major indices would have been worse if it wasn't for the nice rally in the fourth quarter that we're looking at here. The Dow Industrials popping 12 percent this quarter, S&P 500 up 11 percent. Remember it ended the year flat. The NASDAQ gained almost 8 percent over just the past three months.

The worst sector for the past quarter though was the telecom sector, dragged down by AT&T (NYSE:T) dropping its buyout effort of T-Mobile. Today Verizon (NYSE:VZ) was the telecom company canceling plans and deciding not go through with a new $2 fee for some wireless customers paying their bills over the phone or online. Customers and regulators complained about that. Shares gained just a fraction. It was enough to put Verizon (NYSE:VZ) at a new 52-week high tonight, the stock up 13 percent this year.

Two other telecom stocks rallying nicely, prepaid wireless provider Metro PCS jumping more than 5 percent on renewed speculation it could be a buyout target in the New Year. And Frontier Communications (NYSE:FTR) jumping almost 3 percent. Piper Jaffray began coverage of the stock calling it "neutral," but expecting its dividend to continue in the near term.

As we mentioned earlier, bonds beat stocks this year as investors sought safety despite the U.S. losing its AAA credit rating this summer. The interest rate on the 10-year government note fell today down to 1.88 percent. As the rates fall of course, bond prices rise. This is the first year on record the 10-year note has closed out a calendar year with an interest rate below 2 percent. And that is tonight's "Market Focus."

Collectively Americans owe more money on student loans now than we do on our credit cards. Student debt is nearing $1 trillion. This was one of the big issues when college graduates joined "Occupy Wall Street" rallies across the country this fall, many of them voicing concern about rising tuition costs and mounting student debt crisis. Sylvia Hall tonight takes a look at what's fueling soaring college costs and how to pay for them.

SYLVIA HALL, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: If you went to an "Occupy Wall Street" protest, you wouldn't have had to stay long before hearing angry cries of frustrated college graduates. The frustration has been fueled by ever-higher college tuition forcing more students to borrow more money to afford a higher education.

MARK KANTROWITZ, PUBLISHER, FINAID.COM: I'm very pessimistic about college affordability over the next decade.

HALL: Mark Kantrowitz publishes an top financial aid information web site. He says slim government budgets have slashed college and university funding, leading schools to have students pay a higher price. This year alone tuition at four-year public universities is up more than 8 percent from last year according to the College Board. The recession also has dealt a below to financial aid grants leaving students to foot more of the bill than ever before. For many it's a bigger burden than they can afford.

KANTROWITZ: We see this first and foremost with the lower and moderate income students. They're the canaries in the cage that keel over first.

HALL: Jane Wellman heads the Delta Cost Project, a non-profit tracking how colleges use their funds. She points to faculty benefits as one of the largest drivers of school spending.

JANE WELLMAN, EXECUTIVE DIR., DELTA COST PROJECT: We can't expect students to pay for all of this. We shouldn't have to.

HALL: She says many colleges are working to minimize tuition hikes. The school budgets aren't nimble enough to shift quickly.

WELLMAN: The structural problems of higher education finance have been growing for 20 years. But the depth of the recession, the 2008 recession and the slow recovery from it, no one expects this is going to turn around any time soon.

HALL: With prices rising, experts like Reyna Gobel say paying for college doesn't have to become a crisis because Federal student loans carry a variety of payment plans.

REYNA GOBEL, AUTHOR, "GRADUATION DEBT": Whatever you do, don't give up on it, these type of loans. Don't listen to its (ph) bears because you have so much power. You are the consumer. No matter how much money is in your pocket right now, you are the consumer and you have options. And don't let's anybody tell you different.

HALL: President Obama took up the student debt issue earlier this year by easing payback terms on some Federal student loans. But experts say ultimately making college more affordable must come from how states run higher education. Sylvia Hall, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Washington.

HUDSON: Here is what we are watching for next week as 2012 gets under way. December economic data begins pouring in. We'll see auto sales, manufacturing and the number everybody is watching on Friday of next week - - December's employment report. Now Monday with the stock markets closed, we'll bring you an NBR special edition. Women and leadership, focus on Pamela Newman, one of the insurance industry's most powerful women.

While we await the auto industry's December results, strong sales help drive Ford Motor (NYSE:F)'s recovery across the new milestone. 2011 sales of Ford brand cars and trucks topped two million units this week for the year, the first time since 2007 that any single auto brand has hit that mark. Ford's F-series pickup trucks were the top selling vehicle in the nation as they have been for the past three decades. As far as total sales, Ford remains number two U.S. auto maker behind General Motors (NYSE:GM).

President Obama put his request to increase the nation's debt limit on hold. The White House was expected today to ask for $1.2 trillion increase in the government's ability to borrow money. Congressional leaders though asked for a delay saying they would like time to address the measure when they were back in session next month. Lawmakers are not due back in Washington until mid-January. The government is currently within about $100 billion of reaching its borrowing limit.

Despite all the sound and fury this year over European debt problems, quantitative easing here in the U.S. and record corporate profits, 2011 comes to an end, where it pretty much began at least for the S&P 500 stock index. Tonight's "Market Monitor" has one word to describe this year -- dividends. Sam Stovall is the chief investment strategist for Standard & Poor's Capital IQ with us tonight from New York. Happy New Year to you Samuel.

SAM STOVALL, CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER, S&P CAPITAL IQ: Happy New Year, Tom.

HUDSON: Not exactly a bull market, certainly not a bear market, it was a market where shareholders got paid to wait. Is that the best description?

STOVALL: Absolutely. Not a bull, not a bear but a blah market and the investors who focused on quality as well as dividend yields were the ones who were rewarded.

HUDSON: Yeah and you can see that when you take a look at the top three stock sectors in the S&P 500, utilities, consumer staples, health care, kind of defensive but also sectors that traditionally pay their shareholders. What went into that kind of stock performance this year?

STOVALL: I think basically the reason why you had the three best performing sectors post total returns above 13 percent each and not be cyclical sectors in nature is because they were substitutes for bonds. Investors were looking for nice payouts, dividend yields, some sort of a return that was better than money markets and also that would not present them with the potential of a bubble as some investors fear with the bond market. So they focused on these good total return sectors.

HUDSON: And at least for the utilities, a sector that really wasn't in the headlines much, not much news going on there and perhaps it benefited from that.

STOVALL: Absolutely. You would have thought that telecom services group would have done better than it did because it does have the highest dividend yield of all 10 sectors in the S&P 500. But utilities beat out the telecom group, I think mainly as you said because of static demand and very high dividends.

HUDSON: Of course, in the telecom group, it was the big busted deal with AT&T (NYSE:T) and T-Mobile to end the year. Meantime financials, banks were the weakest again. You know, it's tough to get market to move forward when the financials aren't moving forward, isn't it?

STOVALL: It's tough, certainly to get them moving forward for any long-term period. We were able to establish an all-time high back in 2007 when the financials were starting their nosedive. But obviously that advance did not last very long as we saw in 2008. So yes, we have the possibility for short-term advances in the market without the financials, but nothing that I think would be very long lasting.

HUDSON: So here we are again at the end of another year, Sam, you and I speaking pretty much where the S&P 500 was a year ago when we were together. But corporate profits are at record levels, so what kind of valuation does that present investors as we begin a new year?

STOVALL: It presents investors with a very good valuation, actually a 10 percent discount to the median P/E since 1936. And history also says but does not guarantee that you would need to see the yield on the 10-year note rise above 7 percent in order for the P/E on the S&P to be able to fall below 11. So we have very attractive P/E ratios and based on the yield on the 10-year note, not a good likelihood that we'll see single digits any time soon.

HUDSON: With that in mind, we'll take a look at the last year of trading for the S&P 500 and despite all the ups and downs, we are pretty much where we began the year at and we're close to the middle of the range from the April high to the October low. So what is the outlook for the S&P 500 for 2012?

STOVALL: Well, the outlook on a price basis is probably a very, very low double digit advance. Corporate profits are likely to advance by more than 8 percent according to the S&P Capital IQ consensus. Valuations look fairly attractive, no likelihood of a recession in the U.S., in our opinion, unless we are dragged lower by Europe and the possibility of a hard landing in China. And from a technical perspective, our belief is that the market is sort of like a coiled spring, poised to move higher, certainly into the first quarter of 2012.

HUDSON: And of course that also brings up the third and fourth quarter of 2012, big election. Could that hold back any gains?

STOVALL: Well, it could hold back some gains. I think the fact that 2011 the third year of the president's term in office was such a lackluster year, historically it implies that we could end up with a blah 2012 as well.

HUDSON: We'll leave it there. Happy New Year to you, great to see you. It's our "Market Monitor" as we wind up the year, Sam Stovall with S&P Capital IQ.

Finally tonight, when the ball drops in Times Square, New York City tomorrow night, it will ring in more than just the New Year. It also rings in the new energy, independence and security Act. It's a mouth full but to mark the occasion, all 32,000 balls on the Times Square ball are energy efficient. The bill is designed to encourage new lighting technology like LED and halogen bulbs. It's aimed at cutting energy consumption and saving consumers money. Thanks to all of those new balls this year, the Times Square ball drop will use, get this, 88 percent less electricity than previous years.

That's it for us for this year and for tonight. It's NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Friday December 30th, the last trading day of 2011. I'm Tom Hudson. Thanks for joining us. From all of us at NBR, have a happy and safe New Year. We'll see you back here in 2012.

END

urn:contentItem:7XNH-SGV0-Y8Y1-7002-00000-00Nightly Business Report2010-01-28T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:51ZLexisNexisNIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT6:30 PM ESTBUSINESS012801cb.118Nightly Business ReportPaul Kangas, Susie Gharib

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: The ayes are 70. The nays are 30. The nomination is confirmed.

SUSIE GHARIB, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Ben Bernanke wins a second term as Fed chairman despite some harsh criticism from lawmakers.

TOM HUDSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: A look at what this vote means for the nation`s top banker tonight. You`re watching NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Thursday, January 28.

GHARIB: Good evening everyone. Ben Bernanke got the OK from the Senate today; he gets to keep his job. Tom as you know, there was plenty of drama and debate before the vote.

HUDSON: There sure was Susie and when the dust finally had settled on Capitol Hill, lawmakers did vote 70 to 30 to re-appoint Bernanke to another four years now as chairman of the Federal Reserve.

GHARIB: Tom, the controversy over Bernanke`s policies and what they mean for jobs, inflation and the economy won`t go away. He`s still under pressure. As Darren Gersh reports, many politicians will be watching Bernanke now more closely than ever.

DARREN GERSH, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Ben Bernanke`s supporters consider him the indispensable man of the financial crisis. As Federal Reserve chairman, Bernanke pumped more than $1 trillion into the banking system, hoping to prevent another great depression. Sometime this year Bernanke is expected to reverse course, raising interest rates and winding down many of the crisis programs he put in place. Rhode Island`s Jack Reed called that a delicate task and a good reason to give Bernanke a second term.

SEN. JACK REED, (D) RHODE ISLAND: We need someone that understands these programs and understands them not just theoretically, but literally from trial and error, understanding what worked, what didn`t work, what the consequences are.

GERSH: One consequence of waiting too long to take that money out of the banking system could be a burst of inflation. New Hampshire`s Judd Gregg said Bernanke won`t let that happen.

SEN. JUDD GREGG, (R) NEW HAMPSHIRE: As we all know, inflation is the cruelest tax of all. Because it devalues peoples savings and it undermines the productivity of a nation.

GERSH: Other conservatives argued Bernanke`s low interest rate policies created those very inflation risks. And Kentucky`s Jim Bunning reminded his colleagues of what he sees as the Bernanke Fed`s lasting legacy.

SEN. JIM BUNNING, (R) KENTUCKY: A vote for Ben Bernanke is a vote for bailouts. Chairman Bernanke has been in the middle of all the financial bailouts during the crisis.

GERSH: From the left, Democrats pushed the Fed to put Main Street ahead of Wall Street. And Rhode Island Senator Sheldon Whitehouse said it wasn`t just Bernanke who needed to change course.

SEN. SHELDON WHITEHOUSE, (D) RHODE ISLAND: The leaders of President Obama`s economic team must pivot from the necessary rescue of our major financial institutions to equally, if not more necessary, help to America`s families.

GERSH: But today`s confirmation vote was partly about reassuring investors on Wall Street. Some of Bernanke`s strongest supporters argued a no vote would undermine confidence just as the economy and financial markets are finding solid footing. Darren Gersh, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Washington.

HUDSON: Let`s take a look at the stories in tonight`s NBR news wheel for you. Tech stocks leading the way lower on Wall Street. Poor outlooks from Qualcomm and Motorola churned up new worries about the economy. At the close, there it is, the Dow Industrials down 115 points, the NASDAQ down 42 and the S&P 500 off nearly 13. All three now are at new lows for the year.

Results from Microsoft may help set the tone for tomorrow`s trading. The software giant turning in strong fiscal second quarter results with earnings up 60 percent on strong demand for Windows 7. Meanwhile online, amazon.com, huge profits, up 71 percent on robust holiday sales. The company says it`s upbeat about its Kindle e-reader, even with Apple`s iPad launch. We`ll have more specifics on Amazon and Apple coming up in tonight`s "Market Focus."

GHARIB: Something different at Ford, the auto maker says it made money last year. In fact, it`s the first full year profit since 2005. Ford earned almost $3 billion last year, reversing a loss of more than $14 billion in 2008. CEO Alan Mulally expects the profit streak to continue over the next two years, at least before taxes. Driving those profits, sales of Ford`s popular Fusion cars and a turnaround in its finance business. Ford also hopes to take advantage of a competitor`s weakness and win over Toyota buyers. It`s offering $1,000 to customers trading in a late-model Toyota.

HUDSON: As for Toyota tonight, it is waiting for Federal safety regulators to sign off on the fix for its gas pedal problems. With the recall growing, the auto maker known for quality faces some tough questions. Jeffrey Liker is an engineering professor at the University of Michigan and author of the book "The Toyota Way." Professor, welcome to NBR. Has Toyota lost its way with this six million vehicle recall?

JEFFREY LIKER, PROFESSOR, UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN: I don`t think so. Six million sounds like six million problems, but it`s actually two problems that they`ve been able to identify, a problem with carpets when they are loose and a problem with sticky pedals after a few years that has happened in a relatively small number of cars. So I don`t think you could say that. n my experience looking, visiting their plants, visiting their engineering offices, their quality is actually better than ever. For example, 10 JD Power awards for initial quality, the most of any auto maker last year.

HUDSON: But this is certainly front and center in most consumers and investors` minds. Is the recall and how Toyota has been handling it here do you think any indication that the culture of quality perhaps is changing on the edges?

LIKER: I think it`s certainly an indication about the interest of the press and the Internet and how quickly news gets blown up so that you forget it is the pedal and it`s carpet and it becomes the whole company. So I think that gives a very unrealistic impression of what is happening within Toyota.

HUDSON: But certainly isn`t this representative of what Toyota does, which is build cars and perhaps there is nothing more central to a car other than its gas pedal?

LIKER: The gas pedal works in almost every case but after a few years it gets sticky. And it feels sort of awkward. So that also happens in every other car in the world in certain cases. It is not unique to Toyota, but they did find that there is a particular material and a little piece of metal that interacts with moisture and one supplier used that particular material and that is generating all the millions of recalls. It is not certainly indicative of quality in the company. It is not really evidence that...

HUDSON: You`ve studied Toyota for years. You visited plants both in the United States and globally. How prepared do you think the company is to deal with this size of recall, both from the perspective of customers and drivers but as well as shareholders.

LIKER: Well, actually they are probably more prepared than before the recession. One of the things Toyota did in the recession was to keep all their people employed, train them, solve quality problems in the plant. They launched new vehicles. They move vehicles from plant to plant so they are probably more flexible and more prepared than they have ever been before.

HUDSON: In 2001 as you know, Toyota set out to become the world`s biggest auto maker. It did succeed. Do you think that appetite for growth played any role in this recall at all? Those questions are being asked now, I imagine.

LIKER: I know those questions are being asked, again, I think by uninformed people that aren`t realizing this is a supplier and a pedal. And it`s a carpet that if it is not fastened down causes a problem. I don`t know what that tells you about the company, when a company is consistently winning quality awards from JD Power, consistently at the tops of consumer reports.

HUDSON: With all those --

LIKER: The measures are getting better every year.

HUDSON: So with all those awards recognized, why do you think Toyota took the step to actually issue a massive recall as opposed to just deal with these problems as they came in?

LIKER: If you have a pedal, yeah, if you have a pedal that can stick and you meet with NTSA and you decide a recall --

HUDSON: NTSA is the National Transportation Safety Administration.

LIKER: The national, yes, exactly and they meet and they don`t know which of those other cars has that problem. They have no way of knowing. It could be one, it could be 10, it could be 50. So they obviously have to take action. And that`s also the responsible thing to do. But that doesn`t tell you anything about what is going on in their Georgetown, Kentucky plant or the Indiana plant or their engineering office. It is still this one problem that the pedal in one plant that made, in a supplier plant and the designed decision was made 10 years ago.

HUDSON: We have to leave it there. We appreciate you answering questions.

LIKER: You have to go back 10 years.

HUDSON: There we go. Jeffrey Liker along with us, University of Michigan professor, author of "The Toyota Way."

GHARIB: Still ahead, how Toyota is responding to customers on the web. And when it comes to social networking, what your company needs to know about crisis management.

HUDSON: Continuing just a bit with Toyota, it is in tonight`s "Market Focus." With the recall expanding, the company that makes the gas pedal assemblies the professor referred to at the heart of this problem says don`t blame it. That didn`t necessarily help the shares of the company. CTS (CTS), we talked about it last night, again here, after staging a bit of a recovery on Wednesday, today another tough day as you can see, usually about 100,000 CTS shares trade hands. Today more than a million and a half traded and the company said Toyota (TM) is responsible for the bad pedal design, not it. Meantime, CTS says it`s adding extra shifts at three of its factories to make replacement parts. And the company says none of the pedals it sends to Toyota are used by other auto makers. Competing supplier Denso already is Toyota`s biggest parts maker. A spokeswoman tells NBR their Toyota pedals are made in Japan and that it will support Toyota as much as possible, but she would not be specific.

Earlier we did mention today`s big tech earnings from Microsoft (MSFT) and Amazon (AMZN). Let`s take a look at some of the details here. To get the $0.74 a share profit last quarter that you see from Microsoft, it added in deferred revenue. This all relates to the October release of its Windows 7. It sold the software to computer makers two quarters ago before the software was officially released. Those sales are now included in this quarterly report. After hours, Microsoft stock up about $0.40 after dropping almost 2 percent on double normal volume.

Amazon shares certainly catching a bit after the close, up $3 at one point, hitting close to $130 a share, up almost $3 ahead of these results. Santa very kind to amazon.com, a big blow away quarter here. It`s not expected to stop. The company predicts sales to be at least 32 percent higher this quarter. Barclays thinks that Amazon`s Kindle will remain hot even with the new iPad from Apple.

Some of the big movers in the world of mobile phones are moving in different directions. On the downside, Qualcomm (QCOM) after lowering its sales forecast, the stock dropping 14 percent, very active, almost 10 times volume. Motorola (MOT) stock meantime hitting fresh six month lows tonight. The fourth quarter profit not enough to impress buyers because a warning came. Fewer devices from Motorola will be shipped this quarter. The biggest competitor, Nokia (NOK) saw its stock hit three-month highs on six times normal volume. Better than expected results and a bigger slice of the cell phone market helping push shares of Nokia higher.

Let`s catching up on a couple or rather a trio of the Dow components that did report results today, pushing the market around. Pampers maker P&G, Procter & Gamble (PG) did its best to put some green on the board. It was the biggest percentage gainer today, up almost 2 percent for the Dow. Profits beat the Street, thanks in part to price cuts as well as higher priced new products.

Post-it note maker 3M (MMM) was able to show growing profits, pushed up its prediction for the year, not enough though for the stock. Take a look. The shares wane on the index slipping to an early December low.

Let me tell you quickly about AT&T (T) shares, down by only $0.06 in the day, this after matching estimates thanks to its wireless business certainly with Apple`s iPhone.

And a former Dow component turned in a big day of buying. Eastman Kodak (EK), take a look at the stock, 54 million shares, nine times average and at a six-month high, close to a six-month high, its highest price at least since September. Now the Dow Industrials only 120 points above 10,000. Investors here unimpressed with earnings and earnings will continue to be in the "Market Focus."

GHARIB: More on the Toyota recall, as we know, it`s a big story for the news media. But it`s also a big topic of discussion on social media. Toyota has an active social networking presence on Facebook, Twitter and Youtube. It`s answering customer concerns on those sites and on its own web page it has a list of frequently asked questions and answers. This kind of proactive response is exactly what the doctor ordered, according to Scott Gurvey`s guide to social networking. Scott wraps up his series tonight with a look at how businesses should approach these new media platforms.

SCOTT GURVEY, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: If you think the people around you spend a lot of time on social networking sites, you are probably right. And if you are a business hoping to expand through social networking, digital strategy guru Stephanie Agresta says you should plan on making it a part of your regular routine.

STEPHANIE AGRESTA, VP DIGITAL STRATEGY, PORTER NOVELLI: As a business, if you`re making the investment to be there, then you need to be there consistently. It`s not something you can jump into, post, let days go by and then post again. Your customers need to know that you are really committed to the medium.

GURVEY: So, our first take-away tonight is devote time. Nicole Romagnoll spends an hour each day maintaining her pet care company`s Facebook page.

NICOLE ROMAGNOLL, FETCH! PET CARE OF STATEN ISLAND: It`s not work for me. It`s fun. You`re socializing. It`s exciting when you post a picture of a new client and then you get people commenting underneath about how cute. I look forward to seeing that stuff so when I want a break from my day, I`ll go on to my fan page.

GURVEY: One thing to be aware of with social networking is a multiplier effect. Columbia Professor Sree Sreenivasan says it`s both a blessing and a curse.

SREE SREENIVASAN, DIGITAL MEDIA PROFESSOR, COLUMBIA UNIV.: The power of twitter is really in the re-tweet. As in, somebody takes the post you made and then re-tweets it and sends it out. So instead of someone just saying something at the water cooler they`re saying it at the digital water cooler which has this effect of this echo that can make things that are not true seem true and things that are true, they can amplify it in a good way or in a bad way.

GURVEY: Lev Ekster says knowing how quickly a negative comment about his cupcake company can spread keeps everyone on their toes.

LEV EKSTER, FOUNDER, CUPCAKESTOP.COM: All it takes is one dissatisfied customer to send a tweet about you to really hurt the business, so that`s why we try so hard. And we know we have this immense exposure on Twitter now with 9,000 people following us, so it`s important to maintain quality and make sure all those 9,000 people are pleased with you.

GURVEY: Which brings us to our final take-away. Don`t panic. If you get a complaint, social media adviser Jennifer Jacobson says, meet it head on.

JENNIFER JACOBSON, AUTHOR & SOCIAL MEDIA EXPERT: It`s probably not that they just don`t like you and want to say bad things about your business. They probably have a legitimate concern. So step back. Sort of take the emotion out of it and really look at what it is they`re saying and address it honestly. Because if you can have that kind of conversation even over Twitter, your other customers that are following you are going to see that and they`re going to see the tact and the skill and the sincerity with which you addressed that person`s complaint or issue. And hopefully they will respect that.

GURVEY: Our guide to social networking doesn`t end here. There`s more on our web site, NBR on pbs.org and we hope the next chapter in the guide will be written by you. Add your comments and tips for businesses going online to our blog and we`ll keep the dialogue going. Scott Gurvey, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York.

HUDSON: Here`s what we`re watching for tomorrow. We`ll see earnings from Chevron, Fortune Brands, Honeywell and Mattel. And we also get our first look at how the economy did in the final three months of last year. The prediction? Up over 4 percent. And, our Friday "Market Monitor" guest says the economic recovery is the real deal. He`s John Dorfman, chairman of Thunderstorm Capital looking for double digit growth in the year 2010.

GHARIB: Case dismissed against Broadcom founder Henry Nicholas. A Federal judge today threw out drug charges and two civil cases against the former CEO. He had faced the possibility of decades in prison. Last month, Nicholas was cleared of insider trading charges after the judge accused prosecutors of misconduct. Lawyers for the SEC still plan to re- file a lawsuit related to those charges.

HUDSON: If you`re an at-risk homeowner and want help modifying your mortgage from the government, you`ll have to prove your income up front with recent pay stubs and tax returns. Previously, borrowers could provide their income verbally and supply documentation later. That caused problems because many homeowners never got around to doing it. Out of 900,000 trial modifications, only 7 percent or 66,000 have become permanent. The paperwork change begins June 1st.

GHARIB: As we said, Ben Bernanke will be running the Fed for the next four years. But he might not have as much free reign this time around. Some members of Congress want to audit the Fed`s activities. Our commentator tonight thinks that`s a bad idea and he ought to know. He`s Alan Blinder, former vice chair of the Fed and professor of economics at Princeton.

ALAN BLINDER, ECONOMICS PROFESSOR, PRINCETON UNIVERSITY: Do you ever get the feeling that this country is over-lawyered? Well, here`s another example. Ron Paul, the libertarian congressman who wants to abolish the Federal Reserve, has long promoted a first step in that direction. The so- called Paul bill would subject the Fed`s monetary policy decisions to GAO audits. Like most economists, I find the idea, well, appalling. But I breathed a sigh of relief when a modified version was appended to the House`s financial reform bill late last year. The Paul-Grayson amendment added what I thought was an important clause. Let me read it to you. Nothing in this subsection shall be construed as interference in or dictation of monetary policy to the Federal Reserve System by the Congress or the GAO.

That sounds like a strong affirmation of the Fed`s independence, right? I certainly read it that way and so did my students. Then I talked to a lawyer. So put on your lawyers glasses and read it again Nothing in this subsection shall be construed as interference and so on. Read literally, the sentence does not instruct Congress to keep its nose out of monetary policy. Instead, it asserts that the proposed law does not interfere with monetary policy even if you think it does. Orwell`s big brother would have been proud. He gave us war is peace, freedom is slavery. Now the House thought police give us interference is not interference. Ladies and gentlemen of the House, could we please fix this? I`m Alan Blinder.

HUDSON: Finally tonight, when it comes to music, what`s old is now new. Vinyl records once considered obsolete are making a big comeback. Jeff Yastine reports tonight, that`s music to the ears of many fans.

JEFF YASTINE, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: A busy afternoon at Sweat Records. Amid the re-stocking of vegetarian jerky treats, you`ll find other hints of what`s really for sale here. Record adapters? What are those? And along one side of the store, a mother load of vinyl. These are new pressings, not used records. Lauren Reskin presides over this vinyl paradise.

LAUREN RESKIN OWNER, SWEAT RECORDS: Most people are really surprised when they come in, you guys sell records? We get that from older folks are most surprised and then young kids come in and they`re just like ooh vinyl. It`s neat that the perspectives are kind of changing on that.

YASTINE: Some of the albums are iconic, reissues of classic Beatles, Beach Boys, Miles Davis. But right alongside those, you`ll find new releases, from bands you`ve likely never heard of, yet. Reskin says vinyl and digital can peacefully co-exist. In many cases, if you buy a vinyl record, you get the digital download for free. And for the iPod generation, those records come with a new appreciation of cover art.

RESKIN: Like this, on CD it looks like a big jumble of just stuff. But when you blow it up this big, there`s a street scene and some cool graphics and this one comes with a 32-page booklet, liner notes and a comic book and graffiti and downloads. That`s a lot more bang for your buck than just a normal CD.

YASTINE: Vinyl record sales have soared, nearly tripling to 2.5 million records in the last three years. Not bad for a format long declared dead. And here is one of the few places where vinyl records are still made. Linford Ellis is one of the few engineers who still knows how to turn raw vinyl into music. There are only a dozen pressing plants still operating in the U.S., half of what existed 20 years ago.

LINFORD ELLIS, PLANT MANAGER, ALPHA MUSIC MFG.: And most of those people now, they can`t do this job anymore. They`ve forgotten what they`ve learned, so the few people around, the few pressing plants that are around, are still going. We`re like gold dust.

YASTINE: To give you a sense of how much the vinyl record business has taken off, this machine pumps out about 800 vinyl records a day. This is actually a 45 but with a small hole. But now they have a second machine, this one here. It`s also pumping out 800 records as well. Business is so good these days that Alpha is bringing in a third, a fourth and a fifth machine. But these machines are so old that they`re having to scrounge for parts to get them up and running again. That`s a good problem to have, if you`re Jeffrey Collins, CEO of Alpha Music Manufacturing. He`s as surprised as anyone about vinyl`s resurgence.

JEFFREY COLLINS, CEO, ALPHA MUSIC MFG.: It`s exciting. I didn`t think that vinyl was going to continue and last as long as it did. I don`t think vinyl will ever die.

YASTINE: Not everyone agrees. Some think it`s a fad or a love of all things retro. Then again, back at Sweat Records...

RESKIN: In the first year we were around, we expanded our vinyl immensely. And in that first year is when I realized we`re going to sell more vinyl than I anticipated.

YASTINE: That was five years ago. And vinyl, like Reskin`s store is still going strong. Jeff Yastine, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Miami.

HUDSON: And that is NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for this Thursday, January 28. I`m Tom Hudson. Good night to everybody and good night to you too, Susie.

GHARIB: See you tomorrow Tom. I`m Susie Gharib. Good night everyone, hope to see all of you again tomorrow night right here.
