TOM HUDSON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Good evening. I'm Tom Hudson.

SUSIE GHARIB, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Hi, Tom. It's great to be here. Good evening everyone. I'm Susie Gharib.

HUDSON: Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) says it will bring some computer production back to the United States, but why has the stock dropped more than 20 percent this fall?

GHARIB: The fiscal cliff moves to the kitchen table. President Obama visits a Virginia family and tells them how the cliff could impact their budget.

HUDSON: And a very special conversation tonight with Paul Kangas. NBR's founding co-anchor joins us to answer your questions.

GHARIB: We have that and more right here tonight on NBR.

HUDSON: Millions and millions of iPhones, iPads and Mac computers from Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) brag they were designed in California, but admit they were built in China. Next year, some of those Macs will be built in the U.S. too. CEO Tim Cook made the pledge to return to U.S. manufacturing in two media interviews. It marks a return for Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) which transferred most of its technology building to Asia more than a decade ago. It's more of a symbolic move though than a big financial investment. After all, Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) spends more than $9 billion a year on manufacturing and the U.S. commitment is expected to be about $100 million or 1 percent of its global factory investments. Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) didn't say where in the U.S. the line of Mac computers would be built or how many jobs might be included. Now the return of Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) to U.S. manufacturing comes as shareholders have experienced a very rocky ride in the past few months. The stock is down 22 percent from its all-time high in September. Suzanne Pratt reports.

SUZANNE PRATT, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: A peak inside this Manhattan Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) store and it looks like everything is a- OK, plenty of customers, plenty of purchases. So why has the shine come off Apple's shares? Within a word, actually two, profit-taking.

BRIAN COSTELLO, SR. EQUITY ANALYST, MORNINGSTAR: I think the biggest reason for the selling going back to when it was priced $700 in September has been pure profit-taking. If you look from the beginning of the year to September, the stock was up 74 percent. So I think you had some natural profit-taking.

PRATT: But this isn't ordinary year-end selling by institutions looking to record nice numbers. This supposedly is fiscal cliff related selling as shareholders worry that capital gains tax rates will be higher next year. Still, financial planner Sharon Appelman says selling stock solely for tax reasons isn't the best idea.

SHARON APPELMAN, FINANCIAL PLANNER: I definitely think it's a legitimate concern and can be an opportunity. And I would say if somebody was interested in reducing a position anyway, that can certainly be a great time to do it. You know, why pay higher taxes in a few months time when you can pay a lower tax now?

PRATT: And some analysts say, before unloading the shares, consider that fundamentals for Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) haven't really changed. Sure, revenue growth may slow and there are worries the tech giant will have trouble fending off competition from increasingly popular Android products. But to some analysts, the shares look especially cheap today, especially considering their move south since the September high.

COSTELLO: We think the smart phone trend is still in the early to middle innings. It is not in the late innings yet. So we think, to the extent that Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) can maintain its share of the premium smart phone market, we think they'll do quite well. You throw the iPad on top of it and how it's cannibalizing PCs, that's another great growth driver.

PRATT: It is worth noting that Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) shares are still up more than 30 percent this year. Even with more tax-related selling, it will be tough to erase all of those profits in the next few weeks. Suzanne Pratt, NBR, New York.

GHARIB: Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) shares rose more than 1.5 percent today and that gave a boost to stocks. Also better than expected job news encouraged investors. New claims for jobless benefits fell by 25,000 in the week ending December 1 to a lower than expected 370,000 requests and that could be a good sign for the November jobs report that comes out tomorrow and we'll have more on that in just a moment. Separately, American companies announced 57,000 job cuts in November. That's accord to employment firm Challenger, Gray and Christmas, says that's 20 percent higher from October's levels. On Wall Street today, the Dow rose 39 points, the NASDAQ added 15, the S&P up nearly five.

ERIKA MILLER, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: I'm Erika Miller in New York. Coming up tonight, we'll talk to the CEO of kitchen store Sur la Table and get his outlook for holiday sales.

HUDSON: Lots of theatrics today, but few visible signs of progress in Washington towards a fix for the fiscal cliff. The only hopeful sign is that Republicans and Democrats are talking privately again. There remains a lot of work ahead certainly including what to do about the nation's debt limit. Washington will hit its borrowing limit early next year. Darren Gersh has the latest.

DARREN GERSH, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Sitting around the kitchen table with a middle class family in Virginia, the president once again pressed for Congress to avoid the fiscal cliff.

BARACK OBAMA, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: If this family has a couple of thousand dollars less to spend, that translates into $200 billion of less consumer spending next year. And that's bad for businesses, large and small.

GERSH: Behind the scenes, the two sides are talking again. But there was no progress in public. Senators today fought over the debt limit and ended up deadlocked over a bill to allow the president to automatically increase borrowing.

SEN. MITCH McCONNELL, MINORITY LEADER: He's shown what he is really after is assuming unprecedented power to spend taxpayer dollars without any limit at all.

GERSH: If the debt limit isn't raised, the country can't pay for the spending Congress has already approved. And economists say the nation pays a high price for this kind of brinkmanship.

MARK ZANDI, CHIEF ECONOMIST, MOODY'S ANALYTICS: Business people aren't going to engage unless they have clarity with respect to this thing.

GERSH: But few insiders expect to find much clarity from Washington in the coming weeks. Darren Gersh, NBR, Washington.

GHARIB: Investors will be searching for more clarity on those fiscal cliff talks and they will also be studying tomorrow's important jobs report. But Josh Feinman says the November numbers won't give an accurate picture of the labor market. He's chief economist at DB Advisors. Hi, Josh, so you're talking about distortions in that report. Tell us more.

JOSH FEINMAN, CHIEF GLOBAL ECONOMIST, DB ADVISORS: Yes, hi, Susie. I think that the hurricane Sandy may distort the numbers. We've seen it in some of the other high frequency data in the last couple of weeks. Keep in mind tomorrow's labor market report will report on a snapshot of the labor market that was taken in the middle of last month. And that's when the hurricane and its aftermath were having their effects.

GHARIB: So the consensus numbers from a survey of economists, they're expecting American businesses added 110,000 jobs to their payroll. Their unemployment rate staying around 7.9 percent. Does that sit right with you? Is that what you are seeing?

FEINMAN: Probably somewhere around that, maybe a little less. One of the problems is it is hard to gauge exactly what the impact of the storm will have. We know it's transitory but it's hard to say exactly how much numerically it will subtract. The thing is, if the number comes in lower than that I think a lot of people will say oh, it was probably the effect of the hurricane and they'll wait until the following month to see what kind of a rebound we get.

GHARIB: Let's talk a little bit about what we can expect from the job market going forward. I don't know if you saw Alan Blinder's op/ed piece in "The Wall Street Journal." The former Fed governor saying that if we go over the fiscal cliff, the unemployment rate will jump to 11 percent because we'll be a recession and customarily when you are in a recession, the unemployment rate goes up 3 percentage points. Does that sound right to you? And if that is the case, what does this mean for consumers and for businesses?

FEINMAN: Well, it would be seriously bad news. But I think what is important is not just whether we go over the cliff but how long we stay over there. I mean if it turns out that they need a couple more days to hammer out an accord, I don't think that's going to have a big lasting effect. But if we go over the cliff and all those spending cuts and all those tax hikes go into effect and stay in effect for the whole year, then you would be talking about a very high likelihood of a recession and a rising unemployment, a substantial rise, we can quibble about how much. But it would be seriously bad news for consumers and businesses.

GHARIB: As you know Josh, the Federal Reserve is going to be meeting next week on Tuesday. Certainly this is all going to be a topic around the table. Is there a role for the Federal Reserve in this fiscal cliff back and forth?

FEINMAN: There really isn't a direct role that they can play. This is fiscal policy. The Fed does not make fiscal policy. It makes monetary policy. I think Chairman Bernanke and others have been very clear to stay out of the battle that has to be resolved by the Congress and the administration. Look, I think at the end of the day, they are going to reach some sort of an accord to avert the most draconian aspects of the fiscal cliff. Maybe the 11th, or 12th or maybe even the 13th hour, but I think they are going to reach that because I think they recognize that the consequences of not doing so are so severe.

GHARIB: But let's face it, that even if there is a deal, we're talking about an economy that is going to have to deal with people having higher taxes and dealing with spending cuts. What are you projecting for 2013 real quickly? We have a little time left, for economic growth and unemployment.

FEINMAN: Sure. I think the economy is going to be facing some fiscal drag from the Federal side, but if it is phased in slowly, it's not really austere and abrupt, I think it can handle it because I think the private sector is healing and I'm looking for some improvement in growth by the second half of the year provided that we don't hit a landmine here on the fiscal side.

GHARIB: All right, Josh, thanks so much, great talking with you. We've been speaking with Josh Feinman of DB Advisors.

HUDSON: Nearly a month and a half after super storm Sandy wreaked havoc along the New Jersey shore, President Obama met today with Governor Chris Christie at the White House. The topic was Federal aid for storm recovery. The president is expected to ask Congress for about $50 billion in additional emergency help. Ruben Ramirez is in Seaside Heights, New Jersey tonight, where business owners are still trying to recover. Ruben?

RUBEN RAMIREZ, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Thanks, Tom. Yes, nearly six weeks after super storm Sandy devastated this barrier island off the coast of New Jersey, there's still a curfew in place. A lot of the traffic you see behind me is a lot of those longtime residents from the island and business owners who have been going back day in and day out, trying to recover and repair whatever's left. Some of those business owners we had a chance to speak to today. They say they'll reopen come next summer. You've been in business 33 years. Have you seen this sort of devastation before?

SAM HAMMER, OWNER, CRAB's CLAW INN: No, nothing like this. We -- that's the reason we stayed because they were explaining that there was going to be a terrible storm. But we, of this magnitude we had no idea. This is just like -- hard to believe.

RAMIREZ: Here we are almost six weeks after the storm hit. How soon until you get the business open and up and running again?

JIM BOEKHOLT, OWNER, BEN FRANKLIN: There's a few problems -- electrical and structural. But hopefully in the next maybe two months, we might be able to get open again. But definitely we will be open for the summer season.

RAMIREZ: Tom, some of those small business owners we spoke to say they didn't have flood insurance because they say the summer season is short here and the insurance is just too expensive. Tom.

HUDSON: Thanks, Ruben. You'll have more from Seaside Heights tomorrow. We have more on how insurance companies manage risk when it comes to natural disasters Learn about the modeling on our web site, nbr.com. Look for that nbr-u tab.

GHARIB: Americans were feeling a little richer recently, thanks to gains in real estate and the stock market. The Federal Reserve said today that household net worth rose to nearly $65 trillion between July and September. That's up nearly $2 trillion from the previous quarter. Net worth is total assets, like homes and stock portfolios, minus liabilities like mortgages and credit card debt. That wealth effect could make consumers feel more comfortable about shopping this holiday season. There are still 20 days to go before Christmas and the rush is on. Toys are always popular items of course, but there's one category that's expected to do even better and no, it's not electronics. Erika Miller reports.

MILLER: For many families, the holidays are all about the home. Few retailers know that better than Sur la Table, a 104-store chain selling kitchenware and tabletop items. CEO Jack Schwefel says sales are off to a strong start, and credits changing American values.

JACK SCHWEFEL, PRES & CEO, SUR LA TABLE: I think Americans are realizing the importance of the family meal, where people get together. No matter how crazy the day is, you can have that moment every day where it becomes the most important moment of the day and you share it with the people you love the most.

MILLER: Unlike many retailers, Sur la Table says it hasn't had a problem with showrooming this holiday season. That's when people come in to browse, but purchase cheaper versions online. Part of the reason is that 40 percent of the store's products are exclusive.

SCHWEFEL: One of the things that we are most proud of is the fact that we still import more product from Europe than we do from China. So you are talking about artisan product, product that has a story to it, that's special. You just don't see that in retailing in America.

MILLER: Stores like Sur la Table are expected to be one of the few bright spots in an otherwise lackluster holiday season. In fact, some analyst think home goods will be hotter than toys this holiday year. IBM projects home goods will see the strongest sales growth this year, up over 6 percent. That's far more than toys and electronics.

JILL PUFERI, GLOBAL RETAIL LEADER, IBM: You might ask yourself, why home, right? And we think home is up because of a lot of things -- things like the changing demographic of the home itself. There's one stat that says 41 percent of those between 25 and 29 are living back at home.

MILLER: But there also a second reason.

PUFERI: We think that this holiday people are buying what they need versus what they want.

MILLER: Which had me wondering what's on Jack Schwefel's wish list this holiday season. It wasn't this $5,500 coffee maker.

SCHWEFEL: There are some new knives in our store that I'm actually pretty excited about, so probably those. They're cutting board material is actually used in the handle of the knives.

MILLER: And there's no denying it will look good sur la table during the holidays. Erika Miller, NBR, New York.

GHARIB: I know what's on your wish list. A lot of people are buying new housewares. You love cooking.

HUDSON: I do love cooking. Listen I think is great that the house goods category is seeing some good growth here. It says that there is a lot of confidence in the housing market number one. But let's face it, just because it's home goods doesn't mean it's cheap Susie or inexpensive. A $5500 coffeemaker, some of these home appliance blenders can be $500.

GHARIB: If you are looking for discounts Tom, now there is green Monday. We have black Friday. We've had cyber Monday. Green Monday is the second Monday in December and that's when there is a lots of discounts online. So it will be good for consumers.

HUDSON: We've been talking a lot about the fiscal cliff, but I think there is the holiday cliff almost every year which is that game of chicken between stores. Are they going have to discount as we get closer to the holidays or are consumers, shoppers going to spend the money that the stores are asking for right now? Clearly another indication that stores perhaps may be getting a little bit nervous now.

GHARIB: Speaking of green, there was some green on Wall Street today.

HUDSON: There was some buying on Wall Street. Let's take a look at our "Market Focus" here Susie and we saw some better than expected data on first-time unemployment claims leading to a bit of a choppy start for the S&P 500. After Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) went positive in the 10:00 a.m. Eastern time hour, so did the index. Tech stocks turned solidly higher, so did the market, finishing up a third of a percent. Trading volume still moderate, 616 million shares on the big board, just over 1.7 trading on the NASDAQ.

It was the tech sector that led the way, up 0.8 of a percent. Consumer discretionary sector added 0.6 of 1 percent on the session. Now the big tech names in the Dow industrials weren't left out in the rally. Intel (NASDAQ:INTC) had the biggest percentage gains of the Dow 30 stocks. Shares of Intel (NASDAQ:INTC) up 1.6 percent. The CEO said the company could manufacture semiconductors for other chip makers quote, for the right types of products, end quote. So, queue the rumors today that hint about maybe Intel (NASDAQ:INTC) possibly making chips for Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL).

How about Cisco (NASDAQ:CSCO) Systems moving up 1.4 percent. The move takes Cisco (NASDAQ:CSCO) to its highest price since September. The top tech sector stock was Akamai Technologies (NASDAQ:AKAM). It helps speed up and manage online content and traffic. A new partnership announced today with AT&T (NYSE:T) led to the rally. Shares jumping 10 percent on heavy volume. Analysts say the deal turns AT&T (NYSE:T) from a competitor to Akamai's customer, eliminating rival business for Akamai.

On the consumer side, Starbucks (NASDAQ:SBUX) red hot. The company said it will pay more taxes in Britain in the next two years. Yesterday, it also announced plans to open at least 1,500 new stores in the U.S. over the next five years. Shares of SBUX jumping 5.7 percent. Volume tripled today with the stock closing tonight at five-month highs.

How about tax prep giant H&R Block (NYSE:HRB)? It sits at a new 52- week high tonight. It lost less money than feared last quarter. That was seen as good news. H&R Block (NYSE:HRB) has been cutting costs to focus on its core tax preparation business, especially drilling down to the digital tax prep business.

Even satellite radio operator Sirius/XM radio can't resist returning some cash to shareholders this season. It announced a one-time dividend of a nickel per share and a $2 billion stock buyback plan. Sirius shares are consistently among the most actively traded issues on the NASDAQ. Volume was very heavy as you'd expect today. The stock didn't move a whole lot though, up just $0.02. But there was a bigger stock move in Liberty Media Capital. Why Liberty Media? Well, it's the biggest shareholder of Sirius/XM stock. It stands to get $160 million thanks to the special dividend.

Online social gaming company Zynga (NASDAQ:ZNGA) has struggled to repeat the success of its Farmville game. It's going after a gaming license now in Nevada. Don't look it on the strip though. It wants customers to use real money, bet real money on Internet poker. Shares rallying 7.1 percent, volume doubled. Zynga (NASDAQ:ZNGA) has lost more than 70 percent of its value since becoming a publicly traded company.

All of the five most actively traded exchange-traded products were higher with the emerging markets fund up the most, up 0.8 of a percent. And that is tonight's "Market Focus."

GHARIB: And also with some market news, one of the hedge funds embroiled in the FBI's crackdown on insider trading is closing its doors. Diamondback Capital Management is shutting down and that's after clients pulled more than half a billion dollars from the fund. Federal agents raided the Connecticut firm two years ago as part of a nation-wide sweep that resulted in the arrest of one of the firm's former portfolio managers on insider trading charges. Since then, Diamondback's assets have dwindled to just over $1.5 billion, down from $5 billion.

GHARIB: Our viewers have been waiting and he's finally here. Paul Kangas, NBR co-founding anchor. Welcome home, it's so nice to have you back here.

PAUL KANGAS, NBR CO-FOUNDING ANCHOR: Well, it is like home and it's great to hear that I'm still welcome.

GHARIB: Actually, speaking of welcome. We got -- Tom and I got so many viewer questions for you and comments saying that they want to hear from the Walter Cronkite of financial news. A little bit of your wisdom in these confusing time, right, Tom.

HUDSON: Absolutely there is so much going on in the market and you've seen so much market cycles. We got a lot to talk about, but what we have got to ask ,what do you make of the stock market today?

KANGAS: It's sort of a stop and go affair. We get good news one day, better building permits and building news and on that front. And inflation is down a little bit. And then the next day it's all countered by new uprisings in Egypt and one thing or another. So the market tries to step higher and is countered by bad news. So stop and go all the way.

HUDSON: We got a great question from Eric P. Edson. You saw the Dow Industrials move from 1,000 to over 10,000 in your career. He asks, will the Dow Jones see 8,000 or 18,000 first?

KANGAS: Well, there's not that much volatility but it could see both in the same year. But I intend, I'm actually a little on the bullish bias because corporations continue to make money and the American people are basically optimistic. And a lot of stocks are under priced, particularly blue chips even though the Dow Industrial Average has more than doubled since 2009. But there's a reason for that and that's good earnings and that's good dividends.

GHARIB: Well, there's a lot of questions about if that is going to continue. And one of our viewers has a question for you about the fiscal cliff. You know all about the back and forth and the drama about the fiscal cliff and Delores Kile wants your thoughts on where do you stand on this whole fiscal cliff? How can it play out?

KANGAS: Congress better get off its duff and do something. And I think that finally the pressure is going to be enough (ph). But they always do it right to the last, you know, minute. But I think it's got to happen or they're going to be ousted from their hallowed political seats.

HUDSON: You could argue in the three years you've been away from the NBR anchor desk Congress hasn't done a whole heck of a lot to address the fiscal situation.

KANGAS: No it's just ridiculous. I mean these are our elected representatives and they have got to pay a little more attention to those that got them in the office. And they're arguing amongst themselves without much care about the people they represent.

HUDSON: A lot of those folks are retirees, we do have a question about retirement from Anita asking what is the investing or financial planning lesson Paul uses most during retirement?

KANGAS: Well, the number one is hope I can live my life to the last and still have enough capital to keep me going. And a lot of investors are running up against the same thing. They're running out of capital because yields are so low in the bond market; money markets are yielding practically nothing. So they have to chip into their base capital and that's hurtful. So what I am doing is looking for blue chip stocks with decent dividends.

GHARIB: A lot of people are wondering that in this climate, what do you think is going to be the new investment opportunity available to all of us in 2013? That's a question from Fay.

KANGAS: New investment opportunity.

GHARIB: What is your prediction?

KANGAS: They'll come up with something new just like ETF exchange- traded funds were relatively new a few years ago and now have gained such popularity it is almost, it's staggering how much money has gone into ETFs.

HUDSON: You mentioned how volatility could have the Dow see 8,000 and 18,000, maybe in the same year. Frank sent us a tweet on Twitter asking individual investors are afraid of the markets. What needs to be done to gain their confidence?

KANGAS: Less regulation. I think that investors are afraid that they make an investment and something comes along, the rules change from what got them into the investment in the first place. Well you can't change, you know, canoes in the middle of a stream.

GHARIB: On this whole subject of investor confidence, we do have a question from Billy who says what's the greatest changes that you've seen in the market today? You've had some perspective three years being away from it on a day-to-day basis. What do you see as the biggest change?

KANGAS: Well, Billy, I'll tell you that the computer is a wonderful thing, but it's not the greatest thing for investing. And for investors who don't have a high speed capability and have large box of stock at their arm's length. I think that that is -- it's taken away the idea that long- term, long-term investing is a good thing. I think that's one of the changes that I don't like. Too much computer meddling.

HUDSON: Well, Paul, as much as the markets have changed, you haven't. It's great to see and hear from you again. Susie, we have to say good night but I think it's only proper to ask Paul.

KANGAS: I'm Paul Kangas, wishing all of you the best of good buys.

END

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.
 
SUSIE GHARIB, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Oil traders in New York breathe a sigh of relief as OPEC decides not to tinker with production levels-we take a look at what this means for the oil markets. Good evening, everyone. I'm Susie Gharib in New York City.
 
JEFF YASTINE, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: And I'm Jeff Yastine. Paul Kangas is on assignment. Positive news from two big tech names gives Wall Street a boost. The Dow gains 114 points; the NASDAQ climbs 77. Then-this man takes charge of one of the most powerful panels in the U.S. Senate: we sit down with Paul Sarbanes, new chairman of the Banking Committee.

GHARIB: Good evening, everyone. A volatile day in the oil pits today. OPEC ministers decided today at a meeting in Vienna not to increase oil supplies, despite Iraq's move to halt production. Oil prices notched higher in reaction. As Suzanne Pratt reports, oil prices may be stable now-but there are still questions about supply.
 
SUZANNE PRATT, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Just one day after Iraq stunned world oil markets by suspending crude exports, OPEC fired back. The cartel opting to leave its oil output unchanged, at least for now. The decision came after OPEC members held a formal meeting today in Vienna, and decided to meet again next month to review market conditions.
 
Although oil trading here in New York was volatile all day, prices ultimately ended about where they started. Oil for July delivery at the New York Mercantile Exchange gained $0.11 to close at $28.24 a barrel.
 
SCOTT HESS, OIL TRADER, G&H COMMODITIES: Yeah-the markets are very stable because of that news. Basically the markets were looking for a possible increase in output to compensate for the Iraqis cutting back on their production-total production cutback. So the markets are stable, and probably may work higher.
 
PRATT: But experts say, don't expect oil prices to work too much higher, as OPEC is happy with oil trading in a range slightly below $30 a barrel. And OPEC made it quite clear today that if prices warrant, it would decide to pump more oil when it meets again on July 3rd. But experts say OPEC resisted a knee-jerk reaction to Iraq's decision to halt oil sales, because the cartel is comfortable with current supply/demand conditions. As for oil stocks, some analysts say supply constraints will continue to be a big issue in the coming months-constraints caused by global capacity limitations, not by Iraq's erratic behavior. Nevertheless, such conditions are likely to be good news for oil shares.
 
STEVEN PFEIFER, OIL ANALYST, MERRILL LYNCH: We think we clearly are in a period of higher than historical oil prices. We think oil prices will be in a range of roughly $25 a barrel over the next couple of years, and we think that's going to be a very attractive environment for the oil companies and the oil stocks.
 
PRATT: The scheduling of an OPEC meeting in July has raised expectations for a production increase in the third quarter, a time when demand usually picks up and refiners begin building inventories to weather peak wintertime demand.
 
Suzanne Pratt, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York.
 
YASTINE: Today was the technology and telecom group's turn to shine, as investors shrugged off some poor economic news and focused instead on announcements from Lucent (LU) and chip maker, Xilinx (XLNX) instead The Dow Jones Industrial Average helping lead the way higher, churning a bit in the early going, with advancers and decliners about even on the New York Stock Exchange on heavy volume. The Dow then gained traction in late morning, as buyers came in for Intel (INTC), Microsoft (MSFT) and
 
IBM (IBM). And by noontime, the Dow up about 76 point to 11,134.
 
In afternoon trading, the NASDAQ Composite built on its morning rocket- shot, and that report from Xilinx that chip order cancellations had slowed considerably-kept investors in a buying mood. In late trading, there was precious little profit taking, and the
 
Dow going on to close with a gain of 114 points at 11,175. The NASDAQ Composite vaulting 77.75 points, a 3.6 percent gain there to close at 2233.
 
Big board volume back above 1.1 billion shares. No contest between up and down volume.
 
The Transports rising more than 39 points.
 
Utilities falling 8 1/2 though.
 
The Closing Tick bullish at +740.
 
In the broader market, the S&P 500 rising 16 1/2 points, led by strength in computer networking, peripheral and steel makers.
 
The 100 gaining more than 7.
 
The MidCap finished 9 1/4 points higher.
 
And the CRB dipping a fraction there.
 
The NYSE Composite rising 5 1/2.
 
The Value Line picking up 6 1/3 points.
 
The Small Caps, the Russell2000 gaining more than 9.
 
And the Broadly-Based Wilshire 5000 rising 171 points.
 
Bonds rose strongly as mixed economic data showed a weakening economy, but with falling productivity and rising wage inflation. Poor showings in the latest purchasing managers report and new factory orders spurred traders' hoops of more rate cuts by the Fed. And they ignored reports on first- quarter productivity which fell sharply, and labor costs, which rose at the fastest pace in over a decade.
 
So corporate and tax free issues rose, and so did Treasuries.
 
The 5-year note gaining 12/32.
 
The 10-year jumping 17/32.
 
And the 30-year bond gaining a similar amount, the yield at 5.66 percent.
 
Finally, the Lehman Brothers Long Bond Index rising almost nine points.
 
I'll be back later with more of the activity on Wall Street. Susie.
 
GHARIB: Jeff, a victory today for the struggling steel industry. President Bush called for action that could lead to strict limits on imported steel. The International Trade Commission will look into whether domestic steel makers are being hurt by low cost foreign competition. If they are, imports could be restricted. The move is likely to draw sharp criticism from industries that use steel, like auto makers. And the European Union has already threatened to take the U.S. to the World Trade Organization if imports are limited. Still, Bush said the investigation is in the best interests of the country.
 
GEORGE W. BUSH, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: And it's in our nation's interest to make sure that if there are unfair trade practices in the steel industry, we address them at a very, in an aggressive way, which this administration will do.
 
GHARIB: Major steel producers and labor unions welcomed the news. The chairman of U.S. Steel says that unfairly traded steel has forced 18 domestic producers into bankruptcy and cost 20,000 American jobs.
 
YASTINE: Well, tomorrow morning, Democrats will take charge of the United States Senate for the first time in seven years. And with that, Maryland's Paul Sarbanes will take over the chairman's gavel of the Senate Banking Committee. On Sarbanes' agenda, consumer protection, privacy and oversight of the Federal Reserve. Washington Bureau Chief Darren Gersh, sat down with Sarbanes today and began by asking him what kind of candidates he hopes the President will pick to fill the vacancies on the Fed.
 
SEN. PAUL SARBANES (D), MARYLAND: Well, we'll look to see what the President does. I think by and large that Alan Greenspan has done a good job at the Federal Reserve. I differ with him on occasions, but I think he's been, you know, he's able and responsible. And so if you can send him in the mold of responsible and sensitive policy makers with respect to the monetary policies, which obviously affects the workings of the whole economy, why, we'd be satisfied with that. What we don't need are some sort of rigid ideologues of some sort or another. I don't think anyone really, if they stop and think about that, wants that. And members of the Federal Reserve, because they've got to make a lot of tough judgments under-they've got to look at the facts and the circumstances and make a judgment accordingly.
 
DARREN GERSH, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Now you were quite critical of the Federal Reserve last year for raising interest rates too much, in your view.
 
SARBANES: I thought they went too long and too far. I mean, I think there was a period in there where it was hard to quarrel with them sort of looking at slowing down the economy a little bit, although I'm a big jobs and economic growth person. And I think frankly the economy will take a lot of growth and a lot of low unemployment without necessarily getting an inflation problem.
 
GERSH: But have they come down, in your view, low enough on interest rate since they've been very aggressive and is it maybe time for them to-
 
SARBANES: Well, they have been aggressive. I mean five times in less than in five months, half point cuts, which I think only supports the proposition that last year they sort of allowed it to get away from them.
 

 

 
GERSH: But in your view is Fed policy about right now?
 
SARBANES: Well, I'd be prepared to entertain further cuts because I'm worried about the economy. We're not in a recession. Everyone keeps throwing that word around but, you know, a recession is too successive quarters of negative growth and we're certainly not there. But growth has slowed considerably. The unemployment rate has started to move back up again. And I want the economy, you know, to function in a full employment fashion.
 
GERSH: You said you wanted to hold hearings to look into financial conditions generally. Do you have specific concerns there?
 
SARBANES: No. But I think what the committee should do as a sort of a regular operating procedure is periodically bring the regulators in and say, well, how do you see the landscape, what's happening, do you have any concerns, are you equipped to deal with the situation as you see it and do you have adequate resources. And I would hope fairly early on in this chairmanship to be able to do that.
 
GERSH: Let me ask you about privacy, because all over the country right now people are opening up their mail and they're getting these long privacy forms from their insurance companies and whatnot. Are those forms meaningful to people? Are they working? Are they helping to protect their privacy?
 
SARBANES: Well, we don't know yet, and one of the things I think we would look at in the course of looking at the privacy issue more broadly would be how effective are those existing provisions and how are they working. Now, a lot of people are concerned about privacy in the country. We need to look at that. My own view is that what we did on privacy last year, which is leading to these notices that you made reference to, is not enough. And it hasn't fully resolved that issue in terms of giving individuals control over this information. I think most people if you ask them about the information they provide to a financial institution would say, well, that's my information, not theirs, and that they ought not be able then to take it and sort of do with it as they might wish. And so we need to address that issue.
 
GERSH: Senator Sarbanes, thank you.
 
SARBANES: My pleasure.
 
GHARIB: A bumpy start for trading this morning on the NASDAQ. Its main trading system broke down at 9:15 A.M. as technicians were installing more capacity. Traders were still able to get orders executed through other systems and things were back to normal by 10 o'clock in the morning. Jeff, a NASDAQ spokesman told us that they're going to try again to upgrade the system tomorrow, but they don't know when.
 
YASTINE: Well, that glitch did not hurt tech stocks today. There were plenty of buyers around for those and for the blue chips, as well, with the Dow rising 114 points on the day to 11,175. It's risen more than 260 points in just three sessions, advancers outpacing decliners by a nearly 2 to 1 margin, 199 issues hitting new yearly highs, 13 new lows.
 
Lucent Technologies (LU) rising $0.49, its chairman implementing its turnaround plan says it's on track an reaffirmed third quarter sales will top second quarter levels.
 
Nortel Networks (NT) falling $0.28.
 
Meanwhile, Calpine (CPN) tumbling $2.45. Standard & Poor's reports that concerns are growing for the company will not get paid for contracts with bankrupt Pacific Gas & Electric (PCG). A hearing has been set for July 5th on that matter.
 
EMC (EMC) gaining $2.85, part of that strong technology group today.
 
GE (GE), though, slipping $0.27.
 
Williams Communications (WCG) rising $0.19.
 
Nokia (NOK) gaining $1.65.
 
Pfizer (PFE) falling $0.52.
 
And Deutsche Telekom (DT) edged up $0.14.
 
Corning (GLW) advanced $1.10 on the day.
 
Among the widely helds, Celera Genomics (CRA) rising $3.25. J.P. Morgan is urging investors to revisit the biotech sector because it believes growth is sustainable over the next three to six months.
 
Chevron (CHV) dipped $0.33. The oil firm announced plans to cut gasoline output at two California refineries if they are not exempted from rolling power blackouts this summer.
 
IBM (IBM) shooting up 3 1/4.
 
J.C. Penney (JCP) advanced more than $2 after Lehman Brothers upgraded the stock and said that the company's Eckerd Drug Store assets are worth at least $25 a share alone. It also raised estimates on the year.
 
Micron Technology (MU) rising more than 3 1/2.
 
And shares in USX-U.S. Steel Group (X) heating up, rising $1.70. And as you hear, the Bush administration taking aim at rejuvenating the steel industry. It's launching an investigation into alleged foreign dumping of steel in the U.S.
 
On the plus side, there's Bethlehem Steel (BS), another beneficiary today of that.
 
Dycom Industries (DY) soaring 3 1/2. Third quarter earnings came in at $0.31. That's a $0.05 above Street estimates and also implementing a $25 million buy back plan for its stock.
 
KV Pharmaceutical (KV.A) rising $3.79. It posted fourth quarter operating earnings of $0.26 a share. That was in line with Street estimates.
 
Three-Five Systems (TFS) advanced $1.20. But today the firm began selling a new high resolution test kit that will be used by electronic gear makers.
 
On the down side, FiberMark (FMK) falling $1.75, perhaps some profit taking. A spokesperson says the stock is very thinly traded and has had a huge run-up in recent months.
 
And another one, Global Power Equipment Group (GEG), down 3 1/2. The stock just went public a few weeks ago, 20, and ran up to a top of about $36 a share.
 
The Nasdaq Composite bolting 77 3/4 points higher to 2,233. Volume, 1.8 billion shares and advancers outnumbered decliners by a 24 to 13 margin.
 
Microsoft (MSFT) advanced $1.82.
 
We see a similar move in Cisco Systems (CSCO). A big day for all of the networking equipment stocks.
 
Intel (INTC) rising $1.23. The chip makers all did well today, as well.
 
Check Point Software (CHKP) falling $1.50.
 
Juniper Networks (JNPR) rising $2.14.
 
CIENA (CIEN) rising $4.84.
 
Dell Computer (DELL) rising $1.22 on the day.
 
Applied Materials (AMAT) advancing $2.45.
 
Comverse Technology (CMVT), a big gain there, up nearly $9. First quarter earnings coming in at $0.43 a share.That beat estimates by a $0.01 and it also led analysts to raise their yearly profit estimates by $0.01 as well to $1.79.
 
Siebel Systems (SEBL) gained $2.53.
 
Meanwhile, shares in Ulticom (ULCM) climbed nearly 4.
 
IBM (IBM) plans to integrate Ulticom's Signal Ware products into some of Signal Ware products into some of its products, including Websphere software and select telecom platforms.
 
RF Micro Devices (RFMD) jumped $3.45. Merrill Lynch says the recent pull back from $36 is a "buying opportunity."
 
Xilinx (XLNX) soaring more than 4. This is the company many say was the reason for the tech rally today. Late yesterday the company told analysts it is maintaining its previous first quarter guidance and said cancellations have slowed considerably so perhaps some stabilization there.
 
On the AMEX, the Composite Index jumping 8 3/4 points.
 
Medtox (TOX) rising $2.30. The stock jumped 50 percent in four days. Analysts say there is growing excitement over the company's diagnostic testing business and its clinical trial services unit.
 
Shares in Measurement Specialties (MSS) falling more than 6. Fourth quarter profits nearly doubled. But the stock was down apparently because of concern about higher inventory levels. The company says those are due, though, to acquisitions and its moving of some production to China not because of slowing sales.
 
And finally, the Index Shares all ended on an up note, especially the NASDAQ 100 (QQQ).
 
That's the Wall Street Wrap Up. Susie?
 
GHARIB: Thanks, Jeff. Neither snow, nor rain, nor heat keep the postman from delivering, but high fuel prices could be a problem. The United States Postal Service said today that it expects to post an annual loss of as much as $2.5 billion because of soaring fuel prices and the slow economy. The Postal Service said it might cut out Saturday mail delivery to save money. It's also planning a freeze on hiring and capital spending to minimize losses.
 
YASTINE: Tomorrow, meet Michigan Senator Carl Levin. He's taking a key role in the Senate, chairing the Armed Services Committee.
 
GHARIB: More turbulence for the merger between United Airlines (UAL) and U.S. Airways (U). Transportation Secretary Norman
 
Mineta told NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT that the merger will probably be grounded. Asked if he thinks the deal is dead, Mineta said "If I were to read the tea leaves as they are right now, yes." But United told us it's still committed to the deal and U.S. Airways says it's working with the Justice Department.
 
YASTINE: Well, first he retired from Hewlett-Packard (HWP), now Lewis Platt is retiring from his retirement job running the Kendall-Jackson Winery. Platt joined the winery in 1999 after leaving H.P. The 60-year-old Platt says he plans an active retirement, including serving on several corporate boards, philanthropic work and growing grapes on his Sonoma county ranch. Winery Chairwoman Barbara Banke will take on Platt's CEO duties.
 
GHARIB: Many money managers are having a hard time making money in this market, but one who's doing just fine is Kenneth Heebner, Portfolio Manager of the CGM Funds. His CGM Focus Fund (CGMFX) was up more than 14 percent for the first five months of the year and for the year that ended in May, it was up more than 72 percent. It has 20 to 30 stocks, mostly in small to midcap companies. And when I talked to Heebner earlier today from Boston, I asked him what's the unifying theme behind his successful stock picks.
 
KENNETH HEEBNER, PORTFOLIO MANAGER, CGM FOCUS FUNDS: Well, we've been in some smaller stocks that were not widely followed that were doing well, some restaurant companies, some apparel retailers and some home builders. And basically the stocks are doing well. The earnings are coming through and they're getting better recognized.
 
GHARIB: So, but Ken, what is the key to the success?
 
HEEBNER: Finding companies with good earnings growth and low price to earnings ratios in a market where price to earnings ratios are generally quite high.
 
GHARIB: Ken, give us the names of a few of the top holdings.
 
HEEBNER: One of the top holdings is Skechers (SKX), which is a sneaker company. They're gaining share. It's obviously, there's a fashion element here, but right now the company is really on a roll. Another one is Lennar Corporation (LEN), which is a home builder. I know the economy is soft, but their orders are strong and in the month of May they were up 20 percent. This company doesn't know that business is weak. The stock's selling about seven times next year's earnings. Another company is P.F. Chang's Bistro (PFCB), a restaurant chain They're really the only national chain offering very attractively priced Chinese food, growing at 25 percent.
 
GHARIB: As you look ahead and as you size up the economy and consumer spending, do you think that your stock picking strategy is going to change? Are you going to maybe go to larger cap stocks or are you pretty much going to stick to these smaller and midcap stocks that are in your portfolio?
 
HEEBNER: I think we're going to stay with, as long as the values that I'm looking at are present, we're going to stay with the smaller and midcap stocks. I think we're going to see continued weakness in the economy with the Fed continuing to ease and I think you're going to see market, the companies that are doing well continue to do well in expectation of a stronger economy next year when the economy responds to the Fed stimulus.
 
GHARIB: Now, in your fund you are allowed to short stocks, which is an unusual feature. To what extent has shorting stocks contributed to the success?
 
HEEBNER: We have generally not done a lot of shorting except last year when we saw a tremendous disconnect between the valuation of the technology sector and a lot of the companies in the outlook. We increased the short position during the year to as high as 45 or 50 percent and really kept it there into the beginning of the year 2001.
 
And there were big gains here. Today the short position is less than 20 percent and I really wouldn't expect to go back into the short position of that size going forward.
 
GHARIB: Now, your fund, you do, because you do short stocks, it is an aggressive opportunity fund and so it has a lot of ups and downs. For what kind of investor is it best suited?
 
HEEBNER: I don't think this fund really ought to be a core holding. I think if somebody looked at the portfolio they wouldn't recognize most of the names. I think for most people among mutual funds, short selling is something new. Day-to-day the fund can be more volatile because even though companies have a poor future, they can go up a lot in a single day when you're short.
 
GHARIB: OK. Well, listen, thank you so much. Good luck to you for the rest of the year. We really appreciate your talking to us. My guest tonight, Kenneth Heebner, Portfolio Manager of CGM Funds.
 
YASTINE: And recapping today's market action, gains all around, with the Dow closing up 114, the NASDAQ gained 77.
 
And please be sure to join us at our World Wide Web site, NBR.com.
 
GHARIB: And finally, we've told you about the move of Vermont's Senator James Jeffords out of the Republican Party, but something else is moving too: his desk! Tomorrow morning, workers will move Jeffords' desk to the Democratic side of the aisle, shifting around other desks so that they can make room. Holes have already been drilled for the desks' legs and for phone wiring. On the GOP side, Jeffords sat in the last row. On the Democrats' side, he'll sit in the next to last row between senators from Massachusetts and Montana. And, Jeff, that spot was chosen because his desk apparently could most easily fit there.
 
YASTINE: Well, he may be sitting in the next to last row but everyone knows who he is now, that's for sure.
 
GHARIB: That is sure. And I wonder what his perspective will be whether in the next to last row but on the other side of the aisle, right?
 
YASTINE: Either way it's very important. The man has shifted the presence of power in the U.S. Senate.
 
GHARIB: Absolutely. You're right about that.
 
YASTINE: Well, that's NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Tuesday, June 5th. I'm Jeff Yastine. Goodnight, everyone. Good night to you, Susie.
 
GHARIB: Goodnight, Jeff. I'm Susie Gharib. We'll see all of you tomorrow night.

urn:contentItem:3X6C-FYX0-008R-X29C-00000-00NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT1999-08-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:51ZLexisNexisNIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT (NPR 6:30:00 pm ET)Business99081701-118  NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORTPaul Kangas, Linda O'Bryon


 

 
THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.
 
LINDA O'BRYON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Dell can really sell over the Internet. The company racks up $30 million a day in online sales in the second quarter, helping it rack up better than expected earnings. Good evening, everyone, I'm Linda O'Bryon. Susie Gharib is off tonight.
 
PAUL KANGAS, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: And I'm Paul Kangas. More good news on inflation sparks a rally in the bond market, and a nice gain in stocks as well. The Dow closes the day up 70 points. The NASDAQ Index gains almost 26. Then the United Auto Workers Union votes to give their leaders a bargaining tool in talks with Ford (F). We'll show you what's at stake in negotiations for a national contract.

Texas-based Dell Computer posted some Texas-sized earnings today after the close of trading. Dell earned $0.19 a share in the second quarter, up a whopping 58 percent from last year and $0.02 better than estimates. The computer maker's strategy of bundling Internet services with its PCs, paid off big time, giving Dell over $30 million a day in online sales. Analyst Art Russell says PC demand is extremely strong right now because everyone wants to be on the Net.
 
ART RUSSELL, COMPUTER ANALYST, EDWARD JONES: We are seeing a huge increase in demand even in what had traditionally been seasonally the weakest quarter of the year, during the summer. Usually the consumer market is strongest back to school and Christmas. And so it's kind of surprising the level of demand we're seeing right now. And that could continue to accelerate throughout the year.
 
KANGAS: Meanwhile, another big tech company announced solid earnings after the close today. Applied Materials earned $0.61 a share in its third quarter, beating Street estimates by $0.08 a share. It also showed sharply higher new orders for the period. Analysts say that may mean the semiconductor industry may finally be coming out of its slump; a slump sparked by the Asian economic crisis.
 
O'BRYON: Good news on the inflation front gave Wall Street reason to cheer today. The Consumer Price Index is the last major piece of economic data that the Federal Reserve will examine before its meeting next week. But will it keep the Fed from raising rates? Erika Miller reports.
 
ERIKA MILLER, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: In malls across America, clothing and computer prices have been falling sharply. Those declines are a key reason inflation remained in check at the checkout last month. Even rising prices for gasoline, cigarettes, and airline tickets didn't cause much of an up-tick in the Consumer Price Index. It rose a mild 3/10 of a percent in July, in line with expectations. The core rate, which excludes volatile food and energy costs, rose even less.
 
STEPHEN SLIFER, CHIEF ECONOMIST, LEHMAN BROTHERS: The thing that's amazing to me is that in the first seven months of this year, the core CPI is increasing at a 1.6 percent annual rate. Last year it was 2.5 percent. And you have to go all the way back to 1965 to find a time when core prices were rising more slowly.
 
MILLER: But other data out today is pointing to a strong economy, which some fear will aggravate inflation. First, industrial production posted its biggest monthly increase since March, rising 7/10 of a percent last month. In addition, housing starts rose 5.7 percent in July to an annual rate of nearly 1.7 million units. But housing activity is expected to ease up.
 
DAVID RESLER, CHIEF ECONOMIST, NOMURA SECS: The trend in housing activity has begun to slow. It's almost certainly going to continue to move to slower levels of activity. Why? Because mortgage rates are higher than they were earlier in the year.
 
MILLER: Financial markets cheered the numbers. Bonds held their gains throughout the session, while stocks seesawed. Despite today's mixed economic data, economists say a rate hike is still a foregone conclusion.
 
SLIFER: Like everybody else, we're looking for a rate hike next week. And I think as much of a reason for that as any is just that the markets are expecting it.
 
MILLER: The stock market may be expecting a rate hike, but that doesn't mean it will like it. Higher rates are usually a negative for stocks, because they increase borrowing costs for businesses and consumers. They also increase the attractiveness of fixed income securities. Erika Miller, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, New York.
 
KANGAS: Because the rise in July consumer prices matched expectations on Wall Street, the stock market opened moderately higher, extending yesterday's 73-point rise in the Dow Jones Industrial Average. 45 minutes into the trading session, the Dow rose another 65 points with New York Exchange breadth 8 to 5 positive, while the NASDAQ Index posted a 23 point gain. The early upturn lost its luster as morning trading progressed, partly because news of that stronger than expected rise in July new housing starts might convince the Federal Reserve to keep upward pressure on interest rates. On top of that negative, some market technicians were concerned that this recent rally in stocks was sadly lacking in convincing volume. By noontime then, the Industrial Average fell to a 22 point deficit, the NASDAQ Index was down 12 1/2 points. In early afternoon selling pressures dried up, and in a pattern similar to yesterday, firming bond prices triggered a late rally in stocks. The result was a closing gain in the Dow Industrial Average of 70.29 points putting it at 11117.08. In today's 105 point trading range, the Industrial Average closed right at its best level of the day. The NASDAQ Composite Index finished up 25.94 points at 2671.22. In its 49 point trading range, the Composite Index settled only 8 3/4 points below its very best level of the day.
 
Big board volume perked up a bit from yesterday's very slow pace. We're up to 690 million shares today, and quite a bit more up volume than down volume. Not quite a 2 to 1 ratio.
 
The Dow Transport Index fell 6 2/3 points.
 
But the Utility Index managed to gain .48.
 
The Closing Tick +867.
 
Standard & Poor's 500 up 13.39.
 
A gain of 6.61 in the S&P 100.
 
MidCap 400 gained 1.83.
 
And the CRB Bridge Futures Price Index edged up .33.
 
New York Stock Exchange Composite Index gained 5.82.
 
Nearly a 2 1/2 point rise in the Value Line.
 
Russell 2000 Small Cap Index 2.18.
 
And the broadly based Wilshire 5000 gained 118.69.
 
The bond market pushed the stronger than expected rise in the July housing starts to the back burner, and focused on the benign Consumer Price Index in hopes that might convince the Fed to hike interest rates maybe only one more time this year. Buyers were also encouraged by the solid reception given to DaimlerChrysler's (DCX) $4.5 billion global debt offering today.
 
Despite higher gold and oil futures, tax-free and corporate issues ended with 1/4 to 1/2 point gains, and the Treasury market closed broadly higher.
 
The 5-year notes up 9/32.
 
The 10-year notes had a good day, up 20/32.
 
And the Bellwether 30-year bond up 1 5/32, bringing the yield all the way down to 6.01 percent.
 
And the Lehman Brothers Long-Term Treasury Bond Index gained almost 9 points.
 
I'll be back shortly to show you where the action was on Wall Street today. Linda.
 
O'BRYON: Well Paul, the United Auto Workers Union is turning up the heat on the Ford Motor Company. The automaker is about to negotiate a new national contract with the labor union. But as Diane Eastabrook explains, the UAW isn't happy with Ford's plans to spin off its parts division.
 
DIANE EASTABROOK, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Across the U.S. today, Ford's UAW members cast ballots deciding whether to give the union the right to call a national strike against the automaker. A strike authorization vote before a national contract expires isn't unusual. But this one comes unusually early, nearly a month before the September 14 deadline. Local union leaders say the UAW is sending Ford a message. A proposed spin-off of Visteon, the company's parts division, won't happen without major concessions to the union.
 
DON DEEL, BARGAINING CHMN., UAW LOCAL 588: With Visteon, I think that what they're looking at is keeping those people, those members under the UAW Ford umbrella. In other words, if they spin it off into a separate company, there's a good possibility that they'll want to negotiate a separate contract as well.
 
EASTABROOK: Visteon employs about 80,000 workers worldwide. About a third are UAW members. The division accounted for roughly $18 billion in sales last year. That's about 15 percent of Ford's profits. Analysts say Visteon could be more profitable as a separate company because other auto manufacturers would be more willing to buy parts from a company that is not owned by a competitor. They also argue parts plants aren't as profitable as assembly plants.
 
MARVIN BEHM, ANALYST, DUFF & PHELPS CREDIT RATING CO: There is a lot of investment in the parts-making in terms of machinery and equipment, and the people. The returns, the rate of return just isn't as much as it is in auto manufacturing at the assembly level.
 
EASTABROOK: Officials at both Ford and the union downplayed the significance of today's vote. On the issue of Visteon, a Ford spokesman would only say: "we are talking to the union about many issues, Visteon is one of the them."
 
Some analysts speculate Ford may try to spin off Visteon by the end of this year, and that could put pressure on the automaker to quickly negotiate a new national contract with UAW. Diane Eastabrook. NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Chicago Heights, Illinois.
 
KANGAS: Consumer groups are crying foul tonight over AT&T's plans to be buy MediaOne (UMG) saying the deal could lead to higher cable and Internet access charges. But as Darren Gersh reports, despite the static, analysts believe AT&T will probably still get most of what it wants.
 
DARREN GERSH, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Consumer groups say AT&T's deal to buy MediaOne breaks every Federal rule designed to protect customers from a concentration of cable power.
 
GENE KIMMELMAN, CO-DIRECTOR, CONSUMERS UNION: The AT&T/MediaOne merger is a blatant, blatant violation of our nation's antitrust laws, our nation's competition laws.
 
GERSH: In a letter to regulators today, consumer groups called on the Federal Communications Commission and the Justice Department to block the MediaOne merger, claiming the deal would give AT&T control of almost 50 percent of the cable TV market. FCC guidelines cap the share of total cable households one company can control at 30 percent. But analysts expect the FCC will approve the merger anyway, because it believes AT&T is the best bet to take on the baby bells.
 
SCOTT CLELAND, DIR., LEGG MASON PRECURSOR GROUP: The FCC. and the Justice Department want to be supportive of the AT&T transaction, because AT&T is offering the only potential for local telephone competition.
 
GERSH: AT&T promises to deliver advanced cable, Internet and local phone service. But consumer advocates predict that will benefit only the wealthiest consumers.
 
MATT COOPER, DIR., CONSUMER FEDERATION OF AMER: The gain we would make in the telephone market by AT&T's competition is not worth what we'll lose in the cable TV and broadband Internet markets.
 
GERSH: AT&T says its merger will finally make good on the promises made when Congress passed telecommunications reform, and it says consumer groups are wrong to be worried.
 
JIM MCGANN, SPOKESMAN, AT&T: Their argument is that only a small percentage will benefit. They're wrong about that. All consumers will be able to take advantage of bundles of services, or individual services, if they like.
 
GERSH: The FCC is reviewing the merger, and a decision is expected later this fall. Analysts expect AT&T will prevail, but it may have to sell off its minority stake in cable competitors, like Time Warner (TWX) to reassure regulators. Darren Gersh, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Washington.
 
O'BRYON: Apparently, what its customers want, its customers get. Electronic broker E*TRADE (EGRP) says beginning next month, it will offer after-hours trading to individual investors. The company has entered into a deal with Instinet to provide the service, which E*TRADE says more than 25 percent of its customers requested. The news sent shares of E*TRADE's parent company higher. E*GROUP gained 3 3/8 to close at 30 1/4, Paul.
 
KANGAS: Wall Street's bulls get "E" for effort today taking the market out of a midday slump and here we are in the close with over a 70 point gain at 11,117, comfortably over 11,000 again. About 18 stocks higher for every 12 lower. Forty-eight new yearly highs as against 93 new lows.
 
America Online (AOL) topped the active list on 13.8 million shares, moving up 2 9/16.
 
And then Citigroup (C) up 1 5/16. Anything related to the financial arena today did very well, as the bond market rallied.
 
Disney (DIS) edged up 9/16.
 
Micron Technology (MU) down 2 13/16. That stock has been strong recently, due to higher D-RAM prices, but they're leveling off now and so are some of the stocks.
 
Compaq Computer (CPQ) moved up 1/4, fifth in volume.
 
DuPont (DD) up 1 1/4, helping the Dow Industrial average.
 
AT&T (T) edged up 11/16.
 
Burlington Resources (BR) down 2 9/16. As we reported after the close of trading yesterday, Burlington will acquire Poco Petroleum (POC.M), a Canadian firm for some $2 billion in Burlington stock and some analysts feel that price is a bit too steep.
 
Pfizer (PFE) moved up 11/16.
 
And tenth in volume, Conoco B (COC) stock down 1/4.
 
American Express (AXP) up 4 1/4, was the best point gainer in the Dow Industrial Average. As I mentioned the financial stocks did well today.
 
Goodyear Tire (GT) ended down only 5/16, but traded as low as 54 9/16 this morning. But the company then reported it had little damage in its plants in the area of those nasty Turkish earthquakes, very serious 5.9 on the Richter scale I believe.
 
Hewlett-Packard (HWP) down 6 5/16. Of course it's the Dow's big loser today, but a little profit taking after third quarter earnings came in $0.05 above expectations yesterday.
 
Providian Financial (PVN) up 7 9/16. The company's policy is not to comment on its stock activity, but the drop in interest rates a definite plus factor for the financial stocks as I've mentioned.
 
Williams Sonoma (WSM), the retailer, up 3 13/16. Company in with second quarter earnings nicely higher, $0.12 versus only $0.07 last year and sales up a handsome 23 percent.
 
Xerox (XRX) moved up 1 11/16. Prudential Securities repeated a "strong buy" on that stock.
 
Tiffany & Company (TIF) had a sterling performance today, up 6 5/16. The company in with second quarter earnings at $0.31 a share, way up from last year's $0.19 and $0.07 above the Street estimate. Sales were up 24 percent. Both the Hambrecht & Quist and Standard & Poor's analysts increased earnings estimates.
 
Midway Games (MWY) had a good day, up 1 5/16. The Webush Morgan Brokerage upgraded the stock from "hold" to "buy."
 
Tokheim Corporation (TOK) up 1 1/16. The company's in a three-year contract to supply BP Amoco (BPA) with gas pumps around the world.
 
And Granite Construction (GVA) up almost 2 full points. The company received a $49 million contract from the North Carolina Department of Transportation to rebuild sections of highways 185 and US 70 and the company says, since the passage of the highway bill, its business is booming.
 
Kansas City Southern Industries (KSU) down 4 13/16. The CIBC Oppenheimer Brokerage downgraded it from a "strong buy" to just a "hold."
 
And CSS Industries (CSS) fell 1 3/4. The company has delayed hiring Andrew Kelly as the president of its Cleo Subsidiary because of a dispute with Kelly's prior employer.
 
NASDAQ trading, a gain of nearly 26 points in the Index. Volume up nicely from yesterday. About 21 stocks higher for every 17 lower.
 
Microsoft (MSFT) topped the active list, moving up 1/4.
 
Followed by Dell Computer (DELL) down 5/16, but in after hours trading, Dell stock was trading at 43 after posting those earnings which were $0.02 above the Street estimate for the second quarter.
 
eBay (EBAY) up 11 or 8 3/4.
 
Intel (INTC) up 7/16.
 
Amazon.com (AMZN) gained almost 11.
 
And then Yahoo! (YHOO) up 4 3/8, Internets coming alive today.
 
Cisco Systems (CSCO) gained 3/4.
 
QUALCOM (QCOM) up 11 5/16.
 
Followed by MCIWorldCom (WCOM) up 7/16.
 
And Applied Materials (AMAT) up 1 1/4. Those earnings were $0.08 above estimates in the third quarter, but the stock was down to 67 in after hours trading. Apparently some analysts are concerned about slowing growth in new orders.
 
SilverStream Software (SSSW) went public today and three million shares offered at 16. Opened at 32 1/2. The high of the day 39 3/8, then it backed down about 8 points.
 
Diamond Home Services (DHMS) in the home improvement business is in default on a $42 million credit facility after the company had a 30 percent decline in its July sales.
 
And XOMA Limited (XOMA) down 2 3/4. There's growing concern over the dearth of information about late stage trials of the company's drug called Neuprex.
 
The American Exchange Index up just over 3 points.
 
VSI Holdings (VIS) gained a full point, big percentage gainer of the day. It had a third quarter loss of $0.07 a share versus earnings of $0.07 last year, but the company's confident it will be profitable in the fourth quarter.
 
And Paxson Communications (PAX) dropped 1 3/4 after reporting a second quarter loss of $1.35 a share versus a loss of only $0.07 a year ago.
 
Finally, the Index shares, all on the plus side fractionally.
 
And that's the Wall Street Wrap-Up. Linda.
 
O'BRYON: Well, Paul, mark your calendar. There are only 136 days left until the turn of the millennium. And now is the time to make some decisions about your investment strategy for the year 2000 and beyond. So we're beginning a three-part series on investing in the new millennium. To help you do just that, tonight, Jeff Yastine takes a look at demographics, and how they provide you with some investing signposts.
 
JEFF YASTINE, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Madison Avenue has long kept a close eye on demographics, and now, so is Wall Street. That's because demographic trends can help identify ahead of time the products and services that groups of consumers will want or need. Demographics can also show where growth opportunities are shrinking-in other words, places not to invest. That's something investors like Linda Miller, a mutual fund portfolio manager, also look out for.
 
LINDA MILLER, PORTFOLIO MGR., JOHN HANCOCK FUND: No matter how brilliant the management, or how great the product, how astute their marketing and sales and financial management, if there isn't growth in demand possibility in terms of what's underlying that marketplace, I think over time it's very hard to make money.
 
YASTINE: So what are some major demographic trends you could invest in? One of course, is the baby boom generation, 78 million strong and born between 1945 and 1964, demographers say this group continuing to alter the U.S. economy as it proceeds into old age in the next century.
 
LANNY SACHNOWITZ, MGR., AIM DENT DEMOGRAPHIC TRENDS FUND: We're looking at baby boomers and their impact on the economy, both in their direct spending, in their savings, but also what other new technology and new products are going to emerge as a result of this huge part of the population growing older and spending more money.
 
YASTINE: So how do you invest in this trend? Well, as the boomers age, pharmaceutical and medical device companies are likely to benefit, not only because older people generally require more health care services, but because demographers say, the boomer generation wants to stay young while growing old.
 
Another demographic trend that offers promising investment play, is the growth of the Hispanic-American population. Auto makers and other consumer product manufacturers have noted the rise in Hispanic buying power by advertising directly to that group. And analysts say, they expect television, radio and Internet services that program to Hispanics to benefit most directly.
 
Also, don't overlook the so-called echo boomers, the children of the baby boomers. This group is currently swelling the ranks of teenagers and young adults, boosting sales of items ranging from trinkets to clothing to CDs and movie tickets. Expect similar results as today's teens become tomorrow's college graduates and first time home buyers.
 
Finally, a note of caution. Changing interest rates and economic conditions can throw off projections and investments in some fields like health care tend to be slow in paying off. So analysts say, if you're going to successfully invest with demographic trends in mind you must be a truly long-term investor. Jeff Yastine, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Miami.
 
KANGAS: Tomorrow: it was a hot sector in the 1980's. Now it's coming back strongly. A look at investing in biotechs.
 
O'BRYON: It looks like Home Depot (HD) isn't just for do-it-yourselfers anymore. The home improvement retailer reported strong second quarter earnings today, spurred by sales to a growing number of builders and home repair professionals. The company made $0.44 a share. The Street had been expecting $0.39. But despite the strong earnings showing, Home Depot stock fell today. It lost 15/16 to close at 63 1/16.
 
KANGAS: E-stamp is preparing to go public. The decision comes just one week after the U.S. Postal Service gave E-stamp the green light to sell postage online. E-stamp says the total offering will be worth about $85 million, but did not say how many shares it plans to sell. The company has several big name backers including Microsoft, Yahoo!, and Excite@Home (ATHM).
 
O'BRYON: Recapping today's market action, the Dow gaining 70 points. And the NASDAQ gaining almost 26.
 
Please join us at our World Wide Web site, nbr.com. Or on America Online, keyword "NBR."
 
Well, as we've mentioned, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT is celebrating two decades on the air this year. As part of that observance, each week we'll look back at business and financial news over the last 20 years. Tonight, a look at news of the week of August 16 through the 22. August 18, 1982; an historic milestone for the New York Stock Exchange, as volume tops 100 million shares for the first time ever. Daily volume would mushroom over the next decade and a half, with the first billion share trading day in October of 1997. On August 19, 1991, Wall Street firm Salomon is suspended from buying Treasury securities at auctions on behalf of its clients after admitting it violated bidding rules. Chairman and CEO John Gutfreund and other top officials resigned. Billionaire investor, and Salomon shareholder, Warren Buffet becomes interim chairman. Six years later, Salomon is bought out by Travelers Group, which merges the firm with its Smith Barney unit. August 21, 1995, two drug makers join forces to become a global force in the pharmaceutical industry. Upjohn agrees to merge with Sweden's Pharmacia in a $6 billion deal.
 
And fast forward to 1999, that's NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Tuesday, August 17th. I'm Linda O'Bryon. Good night, everyone and good night to you, Paul.
 
KANGAS: Good night, Linda. I'm Paul Kangas wishing all of you the best of good buys.
