urn:contentItem:587G-T8B1-F0HW-513B-00000-00NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for April 18, 2013, PBS2013-04-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:51ZLexisNexisNIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for April 18, 2013, PBS

ANNOUNCER: This is NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT with Tyler Mathisen and Susie Gharib, brought to you by --

(COMMERCIAL AD)

BILL GRIFFETH, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Tech trifecta. A big night for technology as Google (NASDAQ:GOOG), Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT) and IBM report earnings. We'll look at the winners and the losers.

SUSIE GHARIB, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Stocks slide again. Mixed earnings and a batch of economic numbers that missed projections drag down the major indexes.

GRIFFETH: China's cheap labor -- well, at least that was the case. But as costs rise, are some U.S. manufacturers thinking about pulling out?

All that and more tonight on the NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for this Thursday, April the 18th.

Good evening, everybody, and welcome. I'm Bill Griffeth, in this week for Tyler Mathisen.

And, Susie, it's clear. Once again, that technology is going to set the tone for tomorrow, don't you think?

GHARIB: Three big tech names in the news tonight, Google (NASDAQ:GOOG), Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT) and IBM. Three huge technology companies all reporting their latest quarterly earnings after the bell tonight with mixed results.

The results are important given new concerns about slowing global economic growth. And a sharp decline in the sales of personal computers this year. The report set up a flurry of activity in after-hours trading as the direction of all three companies will impact countless other tech suppliers and component makers on Friday.

And since IBM is the most heavily weighted stock in the Dow, investors will keep close watch on big blue shares tomorrow.

Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT) was the first of the big three to report this evening, and that's where we begin with Seema Mody at the NASDAQ -- Seema.

SEEMA MODY, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Susie, a big day for tech. Let's run through the numbers.

Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT) first -- a lot of concern around weakness and personal computer sales ahead of its earning report, but the numbers are out, and it beat the street by 4 cents on its bottom line. CEO Steve Ballmer said the bold bets we made on cloud services are paying off. The tech heavyweight also announced CFO Peter Klein will be leaving the company at the end of the year. It will name its new CFO in the next several weeks.

Let's also look at Google (NASDAQ:GOOG). Shares are up after hours. The Internet giant reporting an EPS of $11.58 versus a street estimate of $10.66. However, its quarterly revenue of $13.97 billion came in slightly shy of the $14.09 billion expected by the street.

And lastly, big blue IBM, the diversified tech player that is many times seen as a good barometer of what to expect from the broader technology space missed street expectations on its top and bottom line due to a decline in hardware and services sales. Its first quarter EPS came in at $3 a share versus a $3.05 estimate.

The investment group says looking back over the last 10 years, IBM's one-day reaction to earnings has accurately predicted the direction of the S&P 500 over the following five weeks, more than 75 percent of the time. And if that's the case, then tomorrow might be a down day.

We are seeing IBM shares down after hours.

Bill and Susie, back to you.

GRIFFETH: Seema, thank you very much.

And joining us right now to talk about technology and where he thinks it's headed is Ashok Kumar, senior technology analyst at Maxim Group.

Welcome back.

ASHOK KUMAR, MAXIM GROUP SR. TECHNOLOGY ANALYST: Thank you.

GRIFFETH: All three that reported tonight missed on the top line. They were light on revenue. Does that worry you?

KUMAR: No, I think these are cyclical trends. In near term, I think the technology companies are faced with the macroeconomic climate which is weak across the developed markets. And they're seeing customers slow down across key end segments, including PCs and smartphones.

And the service side of the business I think we are seeing hesitancy among the large corporate accounts. So, it's more cyclical in nature than secular.

GHARIB: You know, this has been a tough time for technology companies, technology earnings. And there are so many changes happening in the technology space. And you see a company like Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) once, you know, the darling of the tech sector.

Now it's, you know, kind of a broken company, so to speak. What is it, Ashok, that defines what makes a winner in the technology space versus an also-ran?

KUMAR: Absolutely. I mean, going back to the Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) story, I think the company's meteoric stock rise, you know, from the $100 to its peak to $700 I think reflected disruptive in a product cycle both in terms of price and unit. So the company came in and dominated the tablet market, came in and was creator of significant value in the smartphone segment.

And I think the company has been able to right that cycle, but now, of course, it's on the other side of that mountain, so to speak. So, over $200 billion of market cap has been removed. And so the company is looking forward, our best position, as you pointed out, in this undergoing transformation of the technology value chain, our position at the nexus or the intersection of -- in a consumer or cloud, the information, the mobility and social media, so we think the three companies that should benefit longer term are one, Google (NASDAQ:GOOG), two, Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN) and, three, IBM.

GRIFFETH: We keep hearing the migration to mobile. We all have tablets. We all have smartphones.

What about the PC? Is -- are we looking at the sunset years for the personal computer right now?

KUMAR: I think it's become -- Bill, it's become primarily a replacement in a market. In other words, the life cycle of the PC continues to get extended because of the lack of compelling applications that are being written for the PC platform. So the go-to platform or the post-PC devices as Steve Jobs put it, the smartphones and the tablets, and that's where the application developer community is focused on.

GHARIB: You see a wide range of technology companies. Let me just get back to, you know, which are the ones, the companies that you think have the platforms that are on the cutting edge. And maybe not any of the companies that we've been talking about tonight that reported earnings.

KUMAR: Absolutely. That's a very good point because it seems that investors at the margin are focusing and voting with the dollars and disrupters, and these could be companies like Salesforce, it could be a company like Workday, it could be companies like (INAUDIBLE) networks and moving away from legacy companies like Dell (NASDAQ:DELL), Hewlett-Packard (NYSE:HPQ), EMC (NYSE:EMC) and to a lesser degree, Oracle (NASDAQ:ORCL).

GRIFFETH: And what about an IBM? I mean, so influential for years. They've made this transition through the services industry. They were cutting edge on that. What did you think of their earnings, and where do you think they're going from here?

KUMAR: Bill, you raise a lot of key points on IBM. I think they were early to recognize industry transition away from hardware to software and services in the '90s. So the company's portfolio, if you look at it in a longer-term perspective, it's very counter-cyclical. So they're able to write the software and services, they're in a position to grow, you know, the top and bottom line, high single digits over longer term.

So I think yes, there are some cyclical issues that are buffeting the near-term performance. But from a longer-term perspective, they're very well-positioned to address their customer needs.

GHARIB: So, this has been a big week for technology earnings. A lot of people are wondering, you know, what impact this is going to have on trading tomorrow. Do you think that this latest batch is going to influence stocks to the positive or the negative either way?

KUMAR: No, I think from a training perspective, which is very near- term oriented, yes. But longer term, I think technology sector creates a tremendous amount of value across key markets and segments. It's global in theme, it's secular in themes. So, I think these are cyclical factors that are impacting performance.

But longer term, value proposition in terms of risk return is very compelling on these key technology leaders in the sector.

GRIFFETH: Ashok Kumar of the Maxim Group, good to see you. Thank you for joining us.

KUMAR: Thank you.

GHARIB: On Wall Street today, another day of selling and volatile trading, a round of disappointing economic reports and earnings sent the major averages lower.

The biggest decliner in the Dow, United Health Care, falling nearly 4 percent more. We'll have more on that in our "Market Focus". And the NASDAQ was hit by Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) that we were just talking about, closing before $400 a share for the first time since December of 2011.

Looking at the closing numbers: the Dow down 81 points, the NASDAQ lost 38 and the S&P 500 off 10 points.

Also weighing on the markets, first-time jobless claims rose by 4,000 last week. The Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank said business activity in the mid-Atlantic region slowed down this month. And the read on leading economic indicators unexpectedly declined in March, falling for the first time in four months.

GRIFFETH: But there has been no slowdown in auto sales so far this year. And with sales of cars and pickups revving higher, AutoNation (NYSE:AN) reported a record-breaking quarter before the bell.

The country's largest auto dealership owner reported that first quarter profits rose by 14 percent on a best-ever 68 cents a share with revenues that topped $4 billion. Sales of new and used cars were higher last quarter, getting help from the recovery in housing and the chain even announced plans to expand.

GHARIB: AutoNation (NYSE:AN) CEO Michael Jackson joins us now.

Mike, nice to see you again.

I want to ask you, why is this business so good, and is it safe to say now that the car business is getting back to normal?

MICHAEL JACKSON, AUTONATION: Well, Susie, you have to look at it within the context in the auto industry. We had a depression, a complete crash, a complete breakdown in '08, '09, '10. We could not get financing for our customers. So business practically came to a standstill.

And so, what happened is, it pushed out the average age of cars in America to 11 years old. It's unprecedented. And people really need to do something at this point. The trades we're looking at have 150,000 miles on it. So people stop buying cars, stop repairing cars for several years, and now there's genuine replacement need.

So they come in to talk to us, and we have the best product offering ever, outstanding quality. And by quality, I mean fit, finish, design --

GRIFFETH: Right.

JACKSON: -- innovation, content, and dramatically improved fuel economy. We don't ask customers to downsize or go slower, and you don't have to buy exotic hybrids or electric. Mainstream technology will give you a 25 percent to 30 percent improvement in fuel economy.

And finally, we have the best financing ever because ironically during the downturn that customers continued to pay for the cars.

GRIFFETH: Right.

JACKSON: We were the first payment-to-household made. So the banks have really moved back into financing cars.

So you put it all together, you really have a lot of structural support for this one bright spot in the U.S. economy, the automotive recovery.

GRIFFETH: It's clear to see why you're a superstar salesman, Mike.

One of the trends we've seen in the recovery has been the tremendous strength of the rental -- not the rental -- of the used car market. Is that still the case? Are people tending to buy more used cars than they did in the past?

JACKSON: Well, the used car story is the following. We are selling big improvements in used cars and new cars. And because there's such a shortage of used cars because production came -- was so dramatically low from '08, '09 during the depression, there is a shortage which means the value of the trades are at record highs.

So people, had they come in, not only do we have all those other drivers that are already called out, but then we say listen, we can give you more money for your trade than you're ever going to get. And they say, great, I'm ready to get something newer, whether it's still used or new.

GHARIB: Let me ask you this, Mike. I know you hear this all the time. Everybody's talking about the pros and cons of zero percent interest rates and talking about at some point they're going to go up. When interest rates do go up, will consumers be less likely to be interested in buying a car and to finance it?

JACKSON: No, I think these record low interest rates, everybody knows that it will not continue. I should be clear, the market rate that customers are paying today, let's say around 3.5 percent, 4 percent, if you talk zero percent, that is an incentive that has been bought down by a manufacturer. So, the real world is 3.5 percent, 4 percent.

But customers are used to paying 5 percent, 6 percent, 7 percent on the financing of an automobile. So I don't think the normalization of interest rates to those levels is going to unseat these drivers that I've called out that are driving this recovery. We're in the early innings of this automotive recovery. We're on a journey back to the industry, selling 16 million, 17 million units a year.

GHARIB: So, that's nice to end on an upbeat note.

Thank you, Mike. So good to see you. Mike Jackson, CEO of AutoNation (NYSE:AN).

JACKSON: Good to see you.

GHARIB: And sticking with the theme of retail a little later in the program, we'll look at why Walmart is one earnings report to watch when that sector reports.

GRIFFETH: Meantime, United Healthcare beat earnings estimates and that is where we begin tonight's "Market Focus".

But it wasn't all positive. The company also said first quarter profits dropped because of lower government payments for its Medicare services. The company warned that the sequester would pressure profits the rest of this year, and it did not issue specific guidance for 2014.

United Healthcare was off almost 4 percent to $59 and change, followed by other insurers like Humana (NYSE:HUM), Aetna (NYSE:AET) and WellPoint, all down at least 2 percent at the close.

GHARIB: Dow blue chip Verizon (NYSE:VZ) reported increased profits thanks to its booming wireless business and lower costs. Verizon (NYSE:VZ) activated 4 million iPhones during the quarter. Shares hit a new all-time high today before dropping back to close at $50.91, up almost 3 percent.

PepsiCo also touched a new all-time high today as soft drink price increases helped boost profit margins. Revenues in its snack business improved as well, particularly in China. Pepsi gained more than 3 percent, closing at $81.45 a share.

GRIFFETH: Morgan Stanley (NASDAQ:NBXH) (NYSE:MS) is the last Wall Street bank to report, came in above estimates, helped by a boost in stock trading volume. But investors did focus on weakness in the company's bond trading unit. Morgan Stanley (NASDAQ:NBXH) (NYSE:MS) shares lost more than 5 percent on the day.

And after the close, Vertex Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:VRTX) reported significant progress in test patients with cystic fibrosis. And that sent shares soaring after hours. Vertex's two drug therapy improved patients' lung function in a phase 2 study. Now, shares had closed down at the end of the session. But after the report came out, they were up as much as 50 percent in after-hours trade.

GHARIB: And chipotle reported a blowout 22 percent increase in profits, and that's thanks to stronger sales. And said it expects to open as many as 180 new locations this year. The company restated its guidance of flat to low single-digit same-store growth for the rest of the year.

Shares of chipotle which were down more than 3 percent at the close gained as much as 7 percent in after-hours trading.

And coming up, moving operations to China was a no-brainer for many American companies looking for cheap labor. But that could be all about to change.

First, let's take a look at how the international markets finished the day.

(MUSIC)

GRIFFETH: As you know, consumer spending accounts for nearly 70 percent of U.S. economic activity, and nowhere do Americans spend more money shopping than at Walmart.

As we continue our "Earnings Spotlight," Courtney Reagan tells us how important Walmart's results are to investors and what they might reveal about consumers and other big retailers.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

COURTNEY REAGAN, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): While the bulk of retailers report earnings towards the end of the season, the results are closely monitored by investors trying to take the pulse of the consumer amid continued uncertainty. And for decades running, it's the earnings released from the world's largest retailer that is perhaps the most anticipated.

JAN KNIFFEN: Walmart is the bellwether. And other than the time period where Walmart was doing Project Impact a few years ago, it has always been the bellwether.

REAGAN: A bellwether for good reason. Every week, more than 200 million consumers shop in the nearly 10,800 Walmart retail locations around the world. For the first quarter, Walmart is expected to report revenue of more than $116 billion, with earnings of $1.15 per share.

Walmart's U.S. same-store sales is a key metric investors watch. It measures the amount sales increased or decreased for stores open at least a year. While the retailer has posted a gain in each of the last five quarters, the growth rate shows a downward trend.

(on camera): Walmart competitor Target (NYSE:TGT) is warning investors that its earnings will miss expectations. Saying the lingering cold weather in much of the country has hurt sales of seasonal and weather- sensitive items. Investors are now wondering if Walmart's sales have been equally impacted.

(voice-over): But beyond the financials, investors glean insight from Walmart's consumer research. Every quarter, the company surveys its shoppers to take the pulse of what's concerning them most. Last quarter, Walmart U.S. CEO Bill Simon says his consumers were most worried bout jobs followed by inflation, taxes and gas prices.

Consumers may have concerns, but a number of analysts aren't worried.

KNIFFEN: I think Walmart right now is running as well as Walmart has ever run since I started watching them in 1968. They are doing a fabulous job of bringing product at the price to the customer.

REAGAN: And the stockholders are reaping the benefits. Walmart shares gained 27 percent over the last year, better than the S&P retail index and the broader S&P 500 over the same time period.

For NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, I'm Courtney Reagan.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

GRIFFETH: And tomorrow, we turn our attention to housing and the one company to watch this earnings season.

GHARIB: So many American companies, including many Walmart suppliers, move manufacturing out of the U.S. to plants in China, looking to save money. But things have changed. Rising costs for labor, material and shipping has forced a lot of companies to consider bringing some of those jobs back home.

Phil LeBeau has more from Shanghai.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

PHIL LEBEAU, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Here in Shanghai, U.S. manufacturers who have set up plants here in China are facing a new challenge, rising costs. In fact, a new study out today finds that the total cost of manufacturing in China will rise to the same level as the U.S. by 2015.

For Prince Industries based in Illinois, costs for its plant here in Shanghai are rising faster than expected. For example, labor wages are jumping 12 percent every year due to the competition to attract and retain skilled workers. They've got 110 employees here in China, making components companies sell to firms like Caterpillar (NYSE:CAT) and Honeywell. And the CEO says those rising costs may force him to eventually move out of Shanghai.

MARK MILLER, PRINCE INDUSTRIES CEO: We're looking at different areas in China. Shanghai has been high cost to manufacture, but that was where we initially went to, and all of our customers were in that area. But in the next five to seven years, I would say we'll definitely be somewhere further inland.

LEBEAU: Take a look at how fast hourly wages have climbed here in China compared to India, Mexico and the United States. Meanwhile, China's currency, the RMB, has appreciated more than 25 percent over the last 10 years.

Put those together and you see why the overall cost of manufacturing in China has gone up so rapidly in recent years. Now, analysts believe the cost of manufacturing here in China will be equal to manufacturing in the U.S. within a couple of years.

STEVE MAURER, ALIXPARTNERS MANAGING DIRECTOR: If you go back to 2005, it was pretty common for landed costs from China to be 25 percent to 30 percent less than the cost of manufacturing in the United States. Based on our analysis, that gap has been -- about two-thirds of that gap has been closed.

LEBEAU: The rising costs here in China mean more U.S. manufacturers, will pull out of this country and bring jobs back to the U.S.?

Well, don't expect a huge rush of re-shoring. There may be a few companies to bring jobs back. What's more likely is they will keep their China plants focused on selling to companies here in China while U.S. plants pick up more of the manufacturing for companies in the U.S.

One big advantage U.S. manufacturing plants have over those here in China, productivity. Now, it's improving here in China, but it's still not to the level where it is in the U.S. and because of that productivity, U.S. manufacturing plants have been able to keep their costs in check relative to firms here in China.

Phil LeBeau, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Shanghai, China.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

GHARIB: And tomorrow, we'll look at whether China, the world's largest auto market, is about to become the world's most lucrative market for luxury carmakers.

GRIFFETH: In the meantime, still ahead, SeaWorld is set to make its trading debut tomorrow, but should investors dive in?

First, a look, though, at how commodities, treasuries and currencies fared today.

(MUSIC)

GHARIB: You can call it a whale of a deal. SeaWorld Entertainment -- this is the amusement park behind Shamu, the killer whale -- will sell shares to the public for the first time ever tomorrow at the New York Stock Exchange. It's offering 26 million shares, and they price tonight at $27 each, raising $702 million.

Jane Wells takes a closer look at the company.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

JANE WELLS, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): SeaWorld is hoping its stock market debut will make a big splash.

The company made up of 11 theme parks including Busch Gardens and Aquatica wants to raise hundreds of millions of dollars to pay down debt and grow its business.

UNIDENTIFIED BOY: I want to see sharks and stingrays.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Can't see that stuff in Kansas.

WELLS: SeaWorld was bought by the Blackstone Group back in 2009, and the new owners return it had to profitability. The recession put the business on something of a rollercoaster, but net income swung from a $45 million loss in 2010 to over $77 million in profits last year.

Customers are spending more money, and the company is hoping to attract more international travelers, especially to San Diego.

TONY CHERIN, SAN DIEGO STATE UNIV. PROF. OF FINANCE: SeaWorld is one of the major attractions for those international travelers.

WELLS (on camera): But there are risks. The company says it has nearly $1.7 billion in debt. And when your entire business model is built around 67,000 animals, there are unique challenges.

(voice-over): The company is appealing federal safety violations after an orca killed a trainer in Orlando three years ago. SeaWorld warns it could always be subject to changing regulations or the loss of licenses to keep animals.

But the animals are what make SeaWorld entertainment stand apart from other theme park companies.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: You know, as a kid, I learned and loved Shamu so much, so I can't wait for my son to have that in his life as well.

WELLS: Investors will decide when shares start trading if SeaWorld is a whale of a buy or they best avoid the stock for fear it could end up under water.

For NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Jane Wells, San Diego.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

GHARIB: And tomorrow, we'll be speaking with CEO of SeaWorld, Jim Atchison at the New York Stock Exchange.

And, Bill, I understand that he's bringing a penguin to help him ring the opening bell tomorrow morning.

GRIFFETH: One of the best-dressed bell ringers they've had at the New York Stock Exchange in quite a while. It's a great family story, but can they continue to grow this franchise? It's pretty long in the tooth.

GHARIB: I'll ask him. We'll find out.

GRIFFETH: Exactly.

GHARIB: I'll report back tomorrow.

And that's NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for tonight. I'm Susie Gharib. Thanks so much for watching.

GRIFFETH: I'm Bill Griffeth. Have a great evening. We will see you again tomorrow.

END

urn:contentItem:5S5G-P7B1-JBHT-D31J-00000-00NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for April 20, 2018, PBS2018-04-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:12:51ZLexisNexisNIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for April 20, 2018, PBSWalthamFULL TEXT

ANNOUNCER: This is NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT with Sue Herera and Bill Griffeth.

SUE HERERA, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: At a crossroads. Stocks drop sharply to end the week as bond yields rise and investors try to figure out what's next for this market.

Electric results. G.E. surprises investors with much stronger than expected earnings. Is the worst finally behind the troubled industrial?

Nothing to sneeze at. Allergy season is in full bloom and that is big business for some major drug companies.

Those stories and more tonight on NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for Friday, April 20th.

Good evening, everyone, and welcome. I'm Sue Herera. Bill Griffeth is off tonight.

It was a rough way to end the week. Stocks fell sharply as bond yields rose. The yield on the 10-year hit its highest level since 2014.

Apple's four percent drop dragged the technology sector lower after Morgan Stanley (NYSE:MS) said it expects the company's iPhone sales to disappoint. At the close, the Dow Jones Industrials Average fell 201 points to 24,462. The Nasdaq was off 91 and the S&P 500 lost 22.

Despite today's declines, stocks were higher for the week. And now that we're a few months into an unusual year on Wall Street, many are trying to figure out what happens next.

So, Mike Santoli went looking for some answers.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MIKE SANTOLI, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: The stock market finds itself once again at a crossroads. Nearly three months after reaching a peak, the S&P 500 index is about flat for the year and roughly halfway between that record high and the low of early February. Volatility readings have come down sharply as the market has stabilized. Yet the indexes remain far jumpier than they were all of last year.

Corporate earnings are quite strong, even better than lofty forecasts. Yet investors are not rewarded good results for higher share prices across the board. The market's indecision reflects several factors. Tax cuts and a surging global economy are enriching companies and helping consumers, yet those same factors are pushing interest rates higher. The 10-year treasury has climbed back to 2.95 percent, its high for the year and the level last seen two months ago. The S&P has been caught near or below its current level each time bond yields have been this close to 3 percent.

A surge in oil and other commodity prices and reports of upward pressure on wages have revived inflation concerns and boosted expectations that the Federal Reserve will look to raise short-term rates several more times in the next couple of years. And concerns about big tech stock valuation and the risk of hostile regulations for powerful Silicon Valley companies have slowed this sector, which accounts for nearly a quarter of the S&P 500's value.

While these factors have kept stocks in this neutral zone, the market has made progress on some front. The indexes have held above those February lows throughout all the trade war and political noise of recent months. The valuation of the market has also come down nicely as stock prices have stagnated, while earnings have grown fast.

And investor sentiment is a good deal more subdued than it was in January which is usually a necessary condition for stocks forming a durable base. Taken together, it means t market is approaching the one-third point of the year, clinging to its long-term uptrend. But with plenty to prove before investors can be sure that this was just a routine correction or that it's over.

For NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, I'm Mike Santoli.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

HERERA: And as bond yields head higher, the Federal Reserve Governor Lael Brainard today said the economy is strengthening and appears capable of withstanding gradual interest rate increases. She's also pleased to see inflation moving towards the central bank's target.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LAE: Today, actually, inflation is moving more in line with what one would expect at this point. And, in fact, there I think, you know, we are looking carefully at inflation and expecting to see it move towards target in line with our objectives.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HERERA: So with inflation and interest rates ticking higher, how can investors protect their money and maybe even profit?

Bob Pisani did some digging.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BOB PISANI, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Can you protect yourself against inflation and higher rates? In the last several years, the ETF business has expanded dramatically, with more than 2,000 products in all corners of the market. With rates moving up and inflation issues prominent, is it possible to purchase products that benefit from inflation? You can, but it's tricky.

One of the beneficiaries of inflation concerns has been commodities. So, oil stocks and steel and aluminum producers. Fortunately, there are ways to play the trend. Oil and gas exploration and production ETF, XOP is the simple, is a basket of companies that explore for oil and gas. It's up over 10 percent this month.

And you can play this in an even broader way, the VanEck natural resources ETF, symbol HAP, invest in oil and gas producers but also mining and agribusiness stocks. It's up 4 percent.

You can even get more exotic. How about timber? PowerShares global timber ETF, the symbol is CUT. Invest in timber companies, like Weyerhaeuser (NYSE:WY), an international paper. Why? The theory is that timber-related products have been seen as hedges against inflation in the past.

Now, commodities are not the only play on inflation. Some are buying variable rate loans which rise as interest rates rise. Using ETFs like the PowerShares senior loan portfolio, the symbol is BKLN. Others are trying to short treasury bonds using ETFs. This is a further bet essentially that interest rates will rise.

A lot of choices out there.

For NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, I'm Bob Pisani at the New York Stock Exchange.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

HERERA: The rise in bond yields means mortgage rates are going up. And as Diana Olick reports, the timing couldn't be worse for a housing market that's already facing a number of headwinds.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

DIANA OLICK, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Buying a home just got a little more expensive. And this is a big weekend for buyers as real estate agencies and home builders are running big spring promotions and sales. Mortgage rates which loosely follow the yield on the ten-year treasury hit their highest level yesterday since the end of March, breaking out of a tight range where they've been sitting for a while.

The move came as bond yields surged higher, while the increase won't mean a ton in terms of the average monthly payment for a homebuyer, it could be signaling the start of another steady rise, which we saw at the start of this year. And that can take an emotional toll not just on buyers but on sellers as well. As rates rise, fewer homeowners will want to sell and buy another home because they would likely be giving up record low rates in the 3 percent range to move and pay on a rate closer to 5 percent.

The entire nation is in the midst of a supply crisis and home builders are not ramping up as much as hoped because of higher costs for materials and a labor shortage. That's just pushing home prices ever higher.

For NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, I'm Diana Olick in Washington.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

HERERA: General Electric (NYSE:GE) was the best performing stock on the blue chip Dow index and it's been a while since we've been able to say that. This, after the company reported earnings and revenue that exceed expectations. The CEO says the quarter represents a step forward in that company's turnaround. Investors breathed a sigh of relief, sending shares up nearly 4 percent.

Morgan Brennan has more on GE's results.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MORGAN BRENNAN, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: The Dow's oldest component reporting earnings that beat expectations and it reaffirmed its outlook for a full-year profit and cash flow. On a conference call with analyst, the GE CEO and chairman John Flannery calling the results his first report card, saying, quote, we see signs of progress.

JOHN FLANNERY, GENERAL ELECTRIC CHAIRMAN AND CEO: There's no change to our framework of $1 to $1.07 earnings per share with $67 billion of free cash flow. We expect earnings pressure in power will be offset by better aviation and better health care earnings and lower corporate costs.

BRENNAN: Flannery, who took the helm last August and has been aggressively cutting costs. He's also moving forward with billions of dollars worth of divestitures. Including a locomotive's unit and GE's iconic lighting business. The updates were welcomed by Wall Street because after a month of disclosures, charges and negative revisions, no news has become good news.

STEVEN WINOKER, UBS: I think what they're going to be able to do is look back on 2018 as the bottom, right, and 2019, even if power markets don't recover, they're finding a way to take costs out in an aggressive way, to still drive margin expansion, despite weak power markets. And that's really the trick as well as looking at the portfolio little more objectively.

BRENNAN: When it comes to that portfolio, Flannery again saying all options are on the table, for the bigger update of the long-term future of the industrial conglomerate, expected in the coming months.

Next on tap, the company will host its shareholder meeting next week to bring in new directors to its corporate board. Meantime, G.E. stock did finish the day higher.

For NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, I'm Morgan Brennan at the New York Stock Exchange.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

HERERA: It is time to take a look at some of today's upgrades and downgrades.

Twitter was upgraded to buy from neutral at MKM Partners. The analyst cites factors including user growth and Twitter's mass market potential. The price target was increased to $40. Twitter shares rose 1 percent to $31.91.

Darden Restaurants (NYSE:DRI (NASDAQ:TBUS)) was upgraded to outperform from market perform at Bernstein. The analyst expects Darden's Olive Garden Restaurants to perform well and cites long-term margin expansion. The price target is $105 per share. The shares were up more than 1 percent to $91.05.

Tractor Supplies rating was raised to overweight from neutral at Piper Jaffray. The analyst there citing improving business trends in the agricultural industry. The firm's price target on the specialty retailer is $72 a share. The stock rose just a fraction to $60.33.

Still ahead, 'tis the season for sneezing and sniffling.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MEG TIRRELL, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Spring is here and that means allergy season is upon us. Coming up, a look at why your allergies may be getting worse and at the big business of allergy medicine.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(MUSIC)

HERERA: As many as 1.5 million SunTrust customers may have had their data compromised after an employee stole client contract lists. SunTrust CEO said the employee who has since left that company was working with a criminal third party when those lists were taken. Separately, the bank reported earnings which topped expectations.

Last night, we told you that regulators were close to finding Wells Fargo (NYSE:WFC) $1 billion for forcing customers into car insurance and charging mortgage borrowers unfair fees. Today, that record fine became official. The bank will pay $5 million to the comptroller of the currency and $500 million to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. The fine is the largest ever imposed by the CFPB.

The Justice Department has reportedly opened an antitrust probe into potential collusion between AT&T (NYSE:T) and Verizon (NYSE:VZ). According to "The New York Times (NYSE:NYT)," regulators allege the companies worked together to make it more difficult for consumers to switch wireless carriers. The investigation was opened five months ago. Both Verizon (NYSE:VZ) and AT&T (NYSE:T) fell on this down market day. Other reports said Sprint and T-Mobile also received requests from the Department of Justice.

One of China's top telecom companies is crying foul over the U.S. government's decision to ban American firms from providing components or software to ZTE. As we reported, the ban was imposed this week by the Commerce Department. And as Eunice Yoon reports, ZTE is making its opposition known.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

EUNICE YOON, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: ZTE's chairman called a press conference today to protest a seven-year ban imposed by the U.S. Commerce Department. The ban blocks American companies from selling components to the Chinese smartphone maker. ZTE pled guilty last year for violating U.S. sanctions by supplying to Iran. The company agreed to pay a hefty fine of $900 million and could take steps against the employees involved.

At the press conference, the chairman admitted to being slow to fulfilling the settlement but said the punishment didn't match the crime. Such sanctions could put the company into a coma, he said. We resolutely oppose such an unfair, unreasonable punishments and especially the act of politicizing trade.

The smartphone maker said it would use all legal means necessary to safeguard its rights. There are two competing reactions in China to ZTE's case. One is the attempt to whip up national sentiment to support the company and China's high-tech industry. In the state media, "The China Daily" ran a headline that read p reads the U.S. action against ZTE aims to hit China's 5G advantages.

At the same time, the case has shaken up some people here about the dangers of getting into a trade war with the United States because they realize that the U.S. makes a lot of products that the Chinese need.

On social media, one user said, from this I learned how big a gap there is between China and the U.S. in tech development. Another says only when you have high tech can you have a say.

Experts here have been calling for China to speed up its efforts to develop its own homegrown chip industry.

For NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, I'm Eunice Yoon in Beijing.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

HERERA: Honeywell hikes its forecast for the second time this year. And that's where we begin tonight's "Market Focus".

A strong quarter helped by strength in the company's aerospace business prompted Honeywell to raise its guidance for 2018. Honeywell also said it's taking aggressive action to mitigate any negative impact caused from the new tarries on imported steel and aluminum. Shares rose 1-1/2 percent to $150.57.

Stanley Black & Decker (NYSE:SWK) topped sales expectations but investors were disappointed to see a drop in quarterly profit and a weaker full-year outlook. The tools maker said the new guidance was result of an acquisition and a tax charge. Shares finished down more than 6 percent to144.21.

Schlumberger (NYSE:SLB) said strength in nearly all of its divisions helped earnings and revenue top expectations. The oil field services company also warned the industry will face supply challenges this year and will need new investments to offset a shortage. Shares of Schlumberger (NYSE:SLB) fell about 1.5 percent to $69.23.

And the activist hedge fund Jana Partners disclosed a 9 percent stake in pinnacle food, saying it plans to talk to the owner of Birds Eye and Duncan Hines brands about exploring a potential sale. Jana also plans to nominate new directors and suggest ways that Pinnacle can cut costs. Shares of Pinnacle Foods jumped nearly 10 percent to $60.58.

HERERA: It is time now for our weekly market monitor who has names of stocks he says are the number one winners of the digital economy. The last time he was on back in October, he liked Facebook (NASDAQ:FB), which is down 5 percent, Esperion Therapeutics, which is up 55 percent, and Wave Life Sciences, which is 96 percent higher.

Joining us is Mark Lehmann, president of JMP Securities.

Welcome back. Nice to see you, Mark.

MARK LEHMANN, JMP SECURITIES PRESIDENT: Thanks, Sue. Appreciate it.

HERERA: And congratulations on a couple of those picks. We think that's terrific that you're giving our viewers that kind of advice.

Let's start with -- you're talking about the digital economy. And there have been a number of challenges in the digital economy lately. And some of it involves one of your picks which we'll get to in a second.

But you like Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN). A lot of people think Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN) has run pretty far, pretty fast.

LEHMANN: Well, they're right and it has been in the news as of late. And it has run a lot. But it's one of those names I think you want to continually watch. If you have an opportunity like we've had when it was in the news for other reasons and you got a chance at much lower than it is today, that's when you want to pay attention.

It has moved a lot. It's a volatile name. And when you have volatility, you have an opportunity potentially to buy it at a much more reasonable price when you think the fundamentals won't change and I think that's why Amazon's the top of our list here at JMP Securities.

HERERA: OK, the one stock that has always been in the news I was referring to a second ago is Facebook (NASDAQ:FB). You're taking a bit of a contrarian view on this one.

LEHMANN: We are. And it has been in the news as of late. Everybody knows Mark Zuckerberg's testimony in front of Congress. But the stock I think is much more reasonably priced, despite all the headlines and all the headline risk. I think there will be some regulation. I think they'll be some self-regulation that I think Facebook (NASDAQ:FB) will go through.

But the juggernaut that they have with the consumers and the juggernaut they have with advertisers, I don't think it's going to change. And I think you have a stock at a much more attractive valuation. I think you need to ignore some of the noise you'll get with the current quarter and know that you're still buying a winner at less than 20 times earnings and that's a stock again that I think is the winner in the digital economy. And you got a chance to buy it cheaper, you should.

HERERA: OK, but as an investor, you need to be aware there may be some headline risk with that name, right?

LEHMANN: Absolutely, and I think, you know, you probably haven't heard the last of it. I think there's definitely more of self-awareness they're going through. But I'd pick Mark Zuckerberg and his teammates any day. And I think the juggernaut that they have with their couple billion users and their million daily active users you want to be a part of.

HERERA: OK. We'll wrap it up with Zillow Group. Why do you like it?

LEHMANN: It's another company that's at the top of their game in terms of the sector they're in of the real estate market. It has gone through a little bit of consternation as of late. They talked about expanding some of the breadth of their products lately. It's caused the stock to deteriorate a little bit from its recent highs.

But it is the number one brand in that sector, in the real estate market. All the consumers know that name. I think if they continue to expand their offering, it's more reasonably priced today, and I think nine months down the road, you're going to want to own that stock. Here at attractive levels, it's a good entry point.

HERERA: All right. We'll leave it at that, Mark, thanks so much.

LEHMANN: Thank you.

HERERA: Mark Lehmann with JMP securities. And you can read more about his stock picks on our Website which is NBR.com.

Well, it is spring, and as the temperatures rise, so does the pollen count. And that means millions of people will turn to allergy medicines to alleviate their sneezing and sniffling and watery eyes. And that is big business for a number of companies.

Meg Tirrell has more.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

MEG TIRRELL, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Each spring, the National Cherry Blossom Festival draws more than 1 million visitors to Washington, D.C. Visitors like 74-year-old Sandra Czarkowski, who loves the view but hated the way it made her feel.

SANDRA CZARKOWSKI, ALLERGY SUFFERER: It's deceptive when you see something so beautiful and it really knocks you right over. You can't sleep. You can't breathe. But I cope.

TIRRELL: Czarkowski is one of 50 million Americans who suffer from seasonal allergies which cause irritating symptoms like stuffy nose and itchy ice but also more serious effects from coughing and wheezing to asthma attacks. Dr. Purvi Parikh, an allergist at NYU says seasonal allergies are getting more severe.

DR. PURVI PARIKH, NYU ALLERGIST: Climate change is a big reason for that, because our carbon dioxide levels are now higher, the pollen is much more potent and the plants are almost producing super pollen and the seasons are much longer.

TIRRELL: Allergy medicines are big business for the pharmaceutical industry, drawing more than $2.6 billion in U.S. revenue in the last year, according to data from Nielsen. That's just for over the counter products like J&J Zyrtec, GlaxoSmithKline's Flonase and Bayer's Claritin, and doesn't include prescription medicines.

The cost for consumers can add up.

Sandra Czarkowski uses a prescription inhaler that she says costs her $50 out of pocket.

CZARKOWSKI: There are people that cannot get relief because they can't pay the price.

TIRRELL: But for her and other allergy sufferers like this 26-year-old student and waitress Jessica Fuentes, going without allergy medications is not an option.

JESSICA FUENTES, ALLERGY SUFFERER: I'm just going to be like waterfall of just all over the place I guess. It's, yes, it's an uncomfortable feeling.

TIRRELL: Here's wishing everyone a less sniffly spring.

For NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, I'm Meg Tirrell from the New York Botanical Garden, Bronx, New York.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

HERERA: Coming up, the new ways to get to space.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BRENNAN: I'm Morgan Brennan in Colorado Springs. It is the biggest space conference of the year and one of the hottest topics, blue origin's rocket engines. We catch up with the space company created by Jeff Bezos to talk about space tourism, its next generation rocket and technology. That's coming up on NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(MUSIC)

HERERA: Here's a look at what to watch next week. On Tuesday, Dow components 3M (NYSE:MMM), United Technologies (NYSE:UTX) and Verizon (NYSE:VZ) will report quarterly results. On Wednesday, we'll hear from blue chip Boeing (NYSE:BA). And on Friday, a look at how much the economy grew in the first quarter. And that is what to watch for next week.

President Trump criticized OPEC and the cartel's role in pushing up oil prices. He wrote, quote: Looks like OPEC is at it again. With record amounts of oil all over the place, including the fully loaded ships at sea, oil prices are artificially very high. No good and will not be accepted, end quote.

That tweet sent oil prices lower earlier in the day, but they recovered and settled slightly higher.

OPEC's secretary-general has said that the organization does not have a price objective but is working to restore stability to the oil markets.

The FAA is issuing an emergency directive, ordering inspections of more jet engines like the one involved in the fatal Southwest accident. The new order goes beyond what was previously proposed. Engines with the high number of takeoffs and landings must complete inspections within 20 days. European regulators are also issuing a similar order.

Private American companies are competing to become leaders in the new space race and in the process, phase out our reliance on Russian parts. One of those companies is Blue Origin.

Morgan Brennan is back with us tonight, filing this report from Colorado Springs.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

BRENNAN: Meet Blue Origin's new rocket engine, the BE-4. It represents a crucial step toward intergalactic dominance but it's also a matter of national security.

I think a lot of Americans don't realize that some of the most sensitive security and military missions right now in terms of space are being powered by Russian-made rockets. So, this actually represents really kind of a shift in terms of American manufacturing.

What's the opportunity there?

BOB SMITH, BLUE ORIGIN CEO: The opportunity has to do to replace those rockets and get on to American rockets, buying American payloads. So, it's exciting actually to do that. This is something we developed with our own dollars, so we're excited about the commercial opportunities that that's going to give us.

BRENNAN: Bob Smith is the CEO of Blue Origins, space startup created by Amazon's Jeff Bezos.

At the Space Symposium in Colorado Springs, Smith sowed off the new technology, in his first on-camera interview since taking the helm last year.

SMITH: We spent so much time in development. That's over seven years developing this engine to make it reusable. This engine will actually perform 100 starts, and 100 formations that we'd actually be able to go do.

BRENNAN: The company develops the engine for its own rockets which are expected to begin launching satellites and other payloads into orbit as soon as 2020. But the company also hopes to sell them to United Launch Alliance or ULA. The industry consortium owned by Boeing (NYSE:BA) and Lockheed Martin (NYSE:LMT).

ULA currently relies on Russian engines. Lawmakers want those phased out. So, ULA is developing its own new rockets.

TORY BRUNO, UNITED LAUNCH ALLIANCE PRESIDENT & CEO: We're going to fly Vulcan in the middle of 2020. We're so excited about that. We'll begin introducing reusability elements just a couple of two, three years later. And then full new technologies in an advance upper stage.

BRENNAN: Blue Origin is competing against Aerojet Rocketdyne to build the engine for the Vulcan. A contract its expected to win when the decision is announced, quote, soon.

Smith says it will mean a new revenue stream and fit into a broader strategy taken from the Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN) playbook.

SMITH: Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN) goes and builds capabilities, builds capabilities, gains some customer base and continues to build on that. We're going to do the same kind of strategy of building capability after capability and making sure we get customer adoption as we go along.

BRENNAN: Blue Origin is already courting customers for its own rocket and its space terrorism ambitions plans to carry paying passengers past the edge of space could take flight as soon as this year. It all speaks to the unprecedented role the private sector's playing in this new space race. As billionaire visions now become realities.

SMITH: Well, I think we'll have obviously flying space tourists. We'll be flying several payloads as well. We'll be I think the pre-eminent engine provider in the country. We'll also have our new vehicle that we'll be using not only for civil and commercial but financial security payloads as well. So, I think at that point, we will be in very much the position we want to be as we stand in today.

BRENNAN: For NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, I'm Morgan Brennan in Colorado Springs.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

HERERA: And before we go, here's a look at the day and the week on Wall Street. The Dow fell 201 points. The Nasdaq was off 91. And the S&P 500 lost 22. For the week, the major indices were all fractionally higher.

And that will do it for NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT for tonight. I'm Sue Herera. Thanks for joining us. Have a great weekend, everybody. We will see you right back here on Monday.

END
