(HOUSE JUDICIARY COMMITTEE IMPEACHMENT HEARING)

STEVE LIESMAN, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Third, it confirms their modest growth forecasts for 2020.

Some economists have baked in trade peace and others just aren`t buying it. Goldman Sachs (NYSE:GS) in a report in November wrote, quote: We expect the drag from the trade war to fade gradually although much could go wrong. We now expect a phase one agreement signed in coming weeks, end quote.

But after the president said yesterday, there may not be a trade deal until after the 2020 elections.

Mike Ferally (ph) at J.P. Morgan said, quote: We never swung all the way to thinking trade peace was breaking out. It`s not like we have to do a big pivot here.

Goldman has a more upbeat 2020 outlook at 2.3 percent. J.P. Morgan not banking on trade peace, only 1-1/2 percent. UBS, most pessimistic of all at just above 1 percent.

We contacted a half dozen economists after the president`s comments, most have just about had it with taking out the erasers. On average, they see the fourth quarter of this year and first quarter of next as the bottom of the slowdown.

Growth is seen ramping up to 2 percent by the end of the next year. In general, economists are inclined to assume the worst on trade and be pleasantly surprised if they`re wrong.

For NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, I`m Steve Liesman.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

SUE HERERA, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: And then there`s housing, a pillar of the economy and probably your most valuable asset. A new report tonight paints an unexpectedly harsh picture for the market next year.

And it got the attention of prospect of buyers, sellers, home owners and investors.

Here is Diana Olick.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

DIANA OLICK, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Almost everything is in place for a strong start to 2020 housing market -- growing demand, a stable job market and low mortgage rates. But one critical thing is missing. Enough homes for sale.

GEORGE RATIU, REALTOR.COM SENIOR ECONOMIST: We`re running out of product to sell. So, if you can`t sell it, obviously, even with demand, prices don`t have anywhere to go.

OLICK: Realtor.com is forecasting a slowdown for housing next year, and a potential record low supply of available homes. Low inventory will cause sales to drop just under 2 percent from this year and home prices will flatten nationally. As millennials who will account for half the buying market struggle to afford overheated prices.

RATIU: What they do find in terms of product, they have all upper end for new product. The only existing inventory that they can really enter at is the existing home sales pipeline. And there, they are basically running out of products.

OLICK: In some major markets, realtor.com is predicting prices could go negative, the first time that`s happened since the housing crash. Those cities include Chicago, Dallas, Las Vegas, Miami, Detroit, St. Louis and San Francisco. With home values weakening, sellers will have little incentive to put their homes on the market because nobody wants to catch a falling knife. That will only weaken supplies further.

Home construction is increasing and the forecast is for a 6 percent annual gain. But so far, it has largely been on the upper end of the market, not at the entry level where demand is strongest.

The only good news in this report is that mortgage rates should remain low. But low rates will only help if consumer confidence in housing is high.

For NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, I`m Diana Olick in Austin.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

BILL GRIFFETH, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT ANCHOR: Time to look at some of today`s "Upgrades and Downgrades".

We only have two for you tonight. First, Marvell Technology downgraded to market perform from outperform at BMO Capital. The analyst says that the semiconductor maker stock is reasonably valued right now. Price target, $28. That stock fell about 5 percent today to $23.92.

And Owens Corning (NYSE:OC) (NYSE:GLW) was downgraded to neutral from buy at Bank of America (NYSE:BAC) Merrill Lynch. The analyst says that the long rumored breakup of the fiber glass company is not likely in the near term. Price target, $72. Shares fell a fraction today to $65.43.

HERERA: Still ahead, United Airlines places a multibillion-dollar jet order and it`s a blow to Boeing (NYSE:BA).

(MUSIC)

GRIFFETH: The White House is changing work requirements for some food stamp recipients. The new rules make it more difficult for states to waive requirements that able-bodied adults without children work at least 20 hours a week or risk losing bifurcates. Critics say that that could make hundreds of thousands ineligible for the program. But the administration says it will get more people into workforce.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SONNY PERDUE, SECRETARY OF AGRICULTURE: What we`re doing here, people have to work 20 hours a week or volunteer 20 hours a week or be in job training for 20 hours a week. What we want to do is increase employment. We need these people in the workforce.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

GRIFFETH: The rules take effect in April of next year.

HERERA: European plane maker Airbus announced a major order of its new long range airplane. The buyer is United Airlines, which is purchasing 50 of the jets. It`s an order Boeing (NYSE:BA) could not compete with as it tackles a number of issues, including the grounding of the 737 MAX.

Phil LeBeau has more.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

PHIL LEBEAU, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: United Airlines is turning to Airbus for its next generation of planes, to fly between the East Coast of the U.S. and destinations in Europe. The airline is buying 50 Airbus A321XLR planes. First flight, 2024.

United did not place an order for long-range planes with Boeing (NYSE:BA), in part because Boeing (NYSE:BA) does not have a model that fits United`s needs. Earlier this year, Airline executives expected Boeing (NYSE:BA) CEO Dennis Muilenburg to announce plans for a in new long range model. That never happened, due in part to the grounding of the 737 MAX, which had become the primary focus for the company.

So, airlines like American will fly the new Airbus planes, between destinations that are further apart like the U.S. to Europe where U.S. carriers are battling foreign airlines who get higher marks in a new survey of travelers flying from North America to Europe and Asia.

To Europe, those surveyed by JD Power ranked Turkish Airlines first, then Virgin Atlantic, British Airways and Delta tied for third.

A big reason some airlines ranked higher than others for international trips, what they serve passengers.

MICHAEL TAYLOR, J.D. POWER: The food and beverage service is actually a little bit more important to the satisfaction. And that`s really because food and beverages interaction between, you know, the airline and the staff that`s in the aircraft itself --

LEBEAU: Those flying to Asia put Japan Airlines at the top, followed by Delta, Korean Air and the Japanese carrier ANA.

JD Power says U.S. airlines are not far behind the foreign competitors when it comes to flights to Europe and Asia, and they could further improve as Delta, American and United make further investments in their international routes.

Phil LeBeau, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Chicago.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

HERERA: And we`re learning that Boeing`s chief engineer who led Boeing`s response to the crashes is retiring.

GRIFFETH: Last night, we told you about the transition of power at Google (NASDAQ:GOOG) parent company Alphabet. Gaggle cofounder Sergey Brin and Larry Page are stepping back. And current Google (NASDAQ:GOOG) CEO Sundar Pichai is also going to be become the parent -- the CEO of the parent company Alphabet.

And as Deirdre Bosa reports now, the new boss faces a list of challenges.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

DEIRDRE BOSA, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: It`s the end of an era at one of tech`s biggest and most successful companies.

Google (NASDAQ:GOOG) cofounders Larry Page and Sergey Brin are handing over the reins to engineer-turned-manager Sundar Pichai. Pichai has already been overseeing the company`s core business as Google (NASDAQ:GOOG) CEO but now as Alphabet CEO, is he ready to take the company into the next decade, one that is fraught with more challenges and threats than ever?

Regulatory battles in the U.S. and Europe are brewing. Employee activism is on the rise. And privacy practices are under fire.

Now, Pichai is relatively untested when it comes to the type of battles other big tech CEOs like Facebook`s Mark Zuckerberg and Apple`s Tim Cook have been fighting.

Another challenge for Pichai could be actual control. While he gets the full CEO title, Larry Page and Sergey Brin are still Alphabet`s biggest individual shareholders, they still retain control through their majority voting power.

Day to day, not a lot is changing in Alphabet. Pichai will continue to run Google`s most important and profitable businesses, while now also overseeing its more ambitious moon shot projects.

On the horizon, though, Pichai has his work cut out.

For NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT, Deirdre Bosa, San Francisco.

(END VIDEOTAPE)

HERERA: Campbell`s reports soupy sales, and that`s where we begin tonight`s "Market Focus".

Campbell`s Soup sold fewer of its namesake products in the U.S. in the most recent quarter, but the company did see an increase in its share of the soup market, for the first time in 10 quarters. And its earnings came in better than expected.

That was enough to lift the stock which rose about 2 percent to $48.47. It hit a 52-week high during the session.

Expedia (NASDAQ:EXPE) is replacing its CEO and CFO following a strategy disagreement with the board of directors. Earlier this year, Expedia (NASDAQ:EXPE) sought to unite its brands, including Orbitz, hotels.com and VRBO, but the chairman of the board said the strategy failed and led to disappointing results. Expedia (NASDAQ:EXPE) shares were up 6 percent to $105.56.

Constellation Brands (NYSE:STZ) sold its Ballast Point craft beer unit to a small Illinois brewery for an undisclosed amount. Constellation bought ballast point in 2015 for a record $1 billion. This deal is believed to be below that amount as the market for craft beer has slowed. Shares were off a fraction today to $184.29.

GRIFFETH: G-III apparel group missed sales estimates for the third quarter and they`ve lowered guidance as a result. Company which owns brands like Donna Karan, Calvin Klein and Tommy Hilfiger blamed the shortfall on trade tariffs. G-III fell 2 percent today to $27.89.

Union Pacific (NYSE:UNP) said it sees fourth quarter shipping volume down a little more than 10 percent and the rail operator also expects revenue to slip by about that same amount. But after falling for five straight sessions, the stock actually rose 2 percent today to $171.46.

Instructure is being acquired by private equity firm Thoma Bravo. The price tag is about $2 billion or $47.60 a share. That`s actually 10 percent below yesterday`s closing price. Last month, the education software company said it was reviewing some strategic options. Instructure dropped 8 percent today to $48.75.

HERERA: Following YouTube`s recent landmark $170 million settlement with regulators, for alleged violation of children`s privacy laws, the company is changing its policies and restricting some features around content aimed at kids. But that is not going over well with creators.

Ylan Mui has the story.

(BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

YLAN MUI, NIGHTLY BUSINESS REPORT CORRESPONDENT: Jeremy Johnston normally fills his day was family.

JEREMY JOHNSTON, J HOUSE VLOGS CREATOR: All right. Who wants to help me.

MUI: And plenty of fun.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: One, two, three, go!

MUI: And he shares it all on his YouTube channel with his 2 million subscribers. It`s a full-time job and a big business. It takes up to 40 people to put together all these videos but lately, the most important place for Johnson to be is Washington, D.C.

JOHNSTON: We`re trying to inform the FTC commissioners and legislators how the regulation is going to impact creators who make family-friendly content.

MUI: Johnson is worried his channel and his ad revenue will take a hit. That`s because YouTube is changing the way it handles content aimed at kids. Personalized ads will be banned and features like comments, suggested videos and play lists will be turned off.

It all comes after the company was forced to pay a record $136 million to the Federal Trade Commission over allegations that it illegally collected children`s personal data. Privacy advocates say the change is long overdue.
